name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Martina Dlabajová and Momchil Nekov, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Culture and Education, on a new European skills agenda (2017/2002 (INI)) (A8-0276/2017).

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, we were anxiously awaiting the presentation of the new skills agenda last June. The agenda focuses on one of the most important and important current topics determining our future prosperity and competitiveness in Europe. We in the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe have long advocated this key issue and its promotion among European priorities. At the outset, I would like to thank my colleague Momchil Nekov, co-rapporteur for the report on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education. It is precisely when it comes to new skills that I must say that cooperation between committees has been absolutely essential. Just as it is not possible to talk about employment without a link to the necessary education, we cannot think of education without knowledge of the perspectives and needs of the labor market. Thank you to all colleagues for their helpful cooperation, suggestions and exchanges of views. I am sincerely pleased with the interest in our report and is proof that we are not indifferent to the question of employment and the future of young people in Europe. We live in a time of explosion of knowledge and new technologies, but that is why the knowledge and skills we learn at school become obsolete very quickly. More than half of the 12 million long-term unemployed do not have sufficient qualifications and skill levels. As many as 20% of Europeans do not have adequate reading and writing skills, and even 40% of Europeans have no digital knowledge. They therefore represent a vulnerable group in the labor market. On the other hand, highly qualified young people do work that does not match their skills and ambitions, which is frustrating and demotivating. The paradox of the labor market is the fact that at the same time more than 40% of employers have a great problem finding graduates with the appropriate skills and qualifications. What's wrong here, you ask like me? The mistake is in a poorly set up education system, which does not manage to respond flexibly to the current needs of employers. It is no longer enough to put out a fire with operational measures. We need to change the whole system. AND we need to change the way we look at European labor market issues. We need to connect educational systems with the current needs of the labor market and provide students with not only theoretical but also practical training during their studies. Some old professions disappear completely and, on the contrary, thanks to technological development, completely new professions are emerging. Who will fill these positions when schools are not prepared for these changes? In the report, therefore, we focus on a number of priorities to help align training practices with labor market needs. I am convinced that the successful transition of a graduate to the labor market already requires the cooperation of all actors in education, including employers, and the acquisition of practical experience, or "learning by work". It is these practical experiences and getting to know the work environment that can be very useful when applying for the first job position. Let us support the development of STEM skills, the teaching of which must go hand in hand with the integration of new technologies into education, the development of soft and managerial skills and encourage entrepreneurship from an early age. At the same time, let us not forget to support craft skills and work together to make apprenticeships and technical training more attractive to young people. One of the great challenges and at the same time a great opportunity is the rapid development of digitization. In ten years' time, 90% of all jobs will need a certain level of digital skills, and we need to prepare for that. That is why we draw attention in the report to the need for quality lifelong teacher education and the provision of strong pedagogical leadership. I believe that investing in the professional development of teachers and attracting and motivating new educators is key to skills development. If our economy is to continue to grow and remain competitive, taking the above measures is a necessary step.

name: Момчил Неков
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the co-rapporteur, Mrs Martina Dlabayova, as well as the other shadow rapporteurs, for the constructive work and the good spirit of cooperation that accompanied us during the negotiations and the long work on consolidation. of the final version of the European Parliament's report. I take this opportunity to emphasize my satisfaction that the Committee on Education and Culture works on an equal footing with the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. The result of our joint work is a text that takes into account not only the current needs of the labor market, but offers a broader approach that draws attention to education and its paramount importance in building competent and confident individuals who have the necessary skills to deal with future challenges. The Commission's communication "A New European Skills Agenda" has been long awaited and rightly draws attention to the need to update European education and training systems in line with the rapidly changing economic and social context. However, I am of the opinion that the proposed package of measures, although quite ambitious, focuses mainly on the current needs of the labor market, which is in fact quite dynamic and the skills needed today will not be the skills needed in 10 or 20 years. . In addition, the main role of education systems is not only to prepare staff for business, but above all to contribute to the personal growth of people, to turn them into responsible and engaged individuals. I believe that we need to think beyond the right employment skills and pay attention to those aspects of education that teach young people how to think critically, be creative and be able to make informed decisions. In this line of thought, I would like to draw attention to a few key points that are at the heart of the European Parliament's report. You have to in the first place to strengthen the social dimension of the skills program, which I believe is completely absent in the report itself. There is a consensus that education contributes to social cohesion, the fight against inequality and poverty. However, the skills program proposed by the Commission does not offer a long-term vision that includes participation in pre-school education. Unfortunately, the fight against early school leaving is also not in place. Given that this model of inequality, which has existed since the early years of education, it is not surprising that today in the European Union we have seventy million people who do not have basic reading, writing and arithmetic skills. The only way to overcome this problem is to invest in inclusive education that meets social challenges and provides equal access for all. After all, if we want young and talented people not to leave Europe, looking for a better future and opportunities for realization abroad, we must take care to create suitable conditions for their development in our country. I want to give you an example from my country. Between 1992 and 2015, three million Bulgarians left their homeland, and for a country with a population of seven million, this is a huge number. Among them are mainly engineers, IT specialists, doctors, nurses and teachers. I think he has to draw the appropriate conclusions. Secondly, if we expect any positive change in social and economic terms, we must first change our mentality. Today, employers are not so much looking for higher education diplomas. They need ambitious people with a wide range of horizontal skills such as teamwork, confidence, leadership and entrepreneurship. The truth is that we acquire the most diverse skills outside the formal education system. Last but not least, I share the Commission's vision that attractiveness should be increased of vocational education.In conclusion, I would like to say that I would expect the European Commission to take into account the recommendations made by Parliament.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) and the Committee on Culture and Education (CULT) and, in particular, the co-rapporteurs, Ms Dlabajová and Mr Nekov, for this comprehensive report. We launched the New Skills Agenda in June 2016. Since then, we have delivered on nine of its ten key actions, including the Upskilling Pathways Recommendation and the European Qualifications Framework. Parliament has adopted its position on the Europass Decision, and the Council is making good progress. Discussions have also started on the Commission proposal on graduate tracking. We have launched the Digital and Skills and Job Coalition, the skills profile tool for third—country nationals and the blueprint for sectoral cooperation on skills. And soon we will present the results of the public consultation on the review of the European Framework of key competences that we organised this year. Your report clearly shows that we are going in the right direction. Together, we should keep up the political momentum. We agree with you that, in a fast—changing, global economy, ‘the skills and know-how of our societies are the sole basis for prosperity and for safeguarding our social achievements’. This is why the first principle of the European Pillar of Social Rights states that everyone has the right to quality and inclusive education, training and life-long learning. Your report rightly emphasises the connection between education and employment, and the need to promote cooperation among stakeholders. This is at the very heart of the Skills Agenda. Together, we must break the silos. Your decision for a joint report of the EMPL and CULT committees underscores the cross-cutting nature of the skills agenda. This joined-up approach, working across ministries, extends to national skill strategies, which we are supporting in cooperation with the OECD. Skills are acquired early in life and must be constantly updated. Unfortunately, 70 million Europeans currently do not master the most basic skills. Our Upskilling Pathways Recommendation will make a tangible difference for them. We share your view on the importance of non-formal and informal learning. Member States have committed to putting in place arrangements for validation of these skills by 2018. Work-based learning deserves particular attention. In October, the Commission will present a Council Recommendation on a Framework for Quality and Effective Apprenticeships. Together with the new Erasmus Pro for cross—border apprenticeships, this will boost quality opportunities for young people. Digitisation and globalisation are transforming the way we live and work, reshaping the range of skills needed in our society and in the labour market. While we cannot exactly predict the skills of tomorrow, digital and entrepreneurial skills will certainly be important. Already today, 90% of jobs require digital skills. Through our Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition, seven million Europeans were trained in less than a year. In 2018, the Commission will launch the ‘Digital Opportunity’ scheme, a pilot project giving graduates in all disciplines hands-on experience through cross-border internships in the digital area. Moreover, together with stakeholders, we have developed tools to improve citizens’ skills: the Digital Competence Framework and the Entrepreneurship Competence Framework. And to show what skills are most needed and where, from next year we will publish data on skills needs and trends using big data analysis. The success of the Skills Agenda depends on our joint commitment and efforts. Indeed, the responsibility for education and training lies with Member States. We trust that, with your support, they will adapt and shape the Skills Agenda to meet labour market needs and fulfil citizens’ aspirations.

name: Maria Grapini
text: Rapporteur for opinion Opinion Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - Madam President, as the draftsman of the opinion of the IMCO Committee, I would like to emphasize a few important things to my colleagues. First of all, I would like to congratulate the Commission for adopting a New Agenda for Skills in Europe in 2016. It is absolutely necessary to see what we can do with human resources and we, the IMCO committee, certainly, who deal with the internal market, are confident and convinced that, in order to ensure sustainable growth, social cohesion and job creation, as well as to promote innovation and entrepreneurship, especially for SMEs and the craft sector, it is essential to close skills gaps, address skills mismatches and promote opportunities for social mobility. The Commissioner also pointed out, and we argue, of course, that the Member States have an obligation: the internal market information system must work efficiently and contribute to improving the exchange of data and strengthening administrative cooperation. I also emphasize the need to take into account the real needs of the market and take steps to develop skills.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, our report should help with implementation of the 10 measures of the new skills agenda in order to strengthen human capital, employability and competitiveness. Our approach respects the key role of the Member States and the real possibilities and competences of the EU. Skills are key to the future competitiveness of our economy. We have to address the problem of around 17 million European adults who lack basic skills. We point out that our priority should be to strengthen our human resources, not only for better employability but also for the personal development and success of Europeans as individual human beings. For better skills, we need better teachers. This is essential and I am glad that the report puts much emphasis on their role and their better conditions. I think this is crucial. We highlight the need to develop the skills that are necessary on the labour market. I would like to thank both my co-rapporteurs for their constructive spirit.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: on behalf of the ECR Group - Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is a pleasure for Members of this Parliament to look to the future as they work. It depends on the abilities, skills and knowledge that citizens in our countries will have. My colleagues have mentioned and will certainly mention several positive points in this report during this debate. For me, such a positive is clearly that, looking to the future, we do not forget even our most vulnerable citizens. It is clear from the report that, for example, people with disabilities must be part of change, part of training, non-formal education, part of the important digital changes that await us. However, new skills and opportunities to acquire them must not only concern young people, but every citizen. Our seniors, as well as people with very low qualifications, would have a good chance. We know that such an approach is not taken for granted when thinking about the future, and that is why I am voting in favor of this report.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that workers' skills need to be improved and updated in order to be able to respond to the changing reality of our century. At the same time, however, their labor rights must be secured and improved. The Commission's new skills agenda, with its neoliberal conception, fails in both. It focuses on the profitability and competitiveness of companies and not the real needs of society and employees. It transfers the weight from the holistic form to the simple and scattered skills based on the demands of the market alone. It transforms studies into educational products and proposes the commercialization and privatization of education. It further deregulates labor relations and promotes flexible forms of precarious work under the guise of training. He ostensibly claims that the huge unemployment rates and the brain drain phenomenon that afflicts the countries of the South are not the fault of the policies implemented but of the poorly trained and trained workforce. So with this package we are leading to the restructuring, degradation, fragmentation of both labor relations and education in Europe.

name: Jill Evans
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs. There are some excellent points in this report, such as the key role of non—formal and informal learning, quality frameworks for apprenticeships and internships, and the inclusion of social partners and civil society. Upgrading education and training is a crucial issue in my constituency in Wales, as it is across the EU. And given the recognition that the labour market is dynamic and future skills needs have to be considered, we believe the report could be strengthened by clear reference to the huge innovation and employment potential of renewable energy sources and green technologies and the skills required for those. There’s also a need for a reference to upskilling in relation to migrants, consistent with the action plan on the integration of third—country nationals. So I would ask colleagues to support the amendments that we have put forward.

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the issue is of crucial importance, especially when one thinks of the unemployment figures and youth unemployment in particular, data which fail to fully convey the tragedy experienced by millions of people, especially the Southern Europe, which still bears the signs of a continuing economic crisis. What we have to teach cannot be reduced to just teaching the skills required by the needs of the labor market. If this were the case, in fact, we would distort the crucial role of teaching, which is wider and which must train the citizens of tomorrow, providing technical skills but also and above all civic and analytical skills and the necessary critical spirit. In fact, I remind everyone that functional illiteracy is a European problem and in particular of some states: in Italy, for example, it has been calculated that there are 28% of functional illiterates. So I believe that problems like fake news and cyberbullying can only be solved through education and instruction. I also want to underline how fundamental is the role of teachers who cannot be precarious but, on the contrary, must be protected and their role valued at best. Investments are needed in this sense, without forgetting, moreover, the phenomenon of brain drain. So I ask myself: what solutions does the European Union intend to prepare to stop this phenomenon which once again seems to affect the countries of Southern Europe more significantly? Much remains to be done and this reaction only focuses on some of the problems. This is why we need to do more and keep working.

name: Mara Bizzotto
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the new skills agenda for Europe, which we are debating today, certainly contains positive points, but also negative points. For example, as has already happened in this House, I find it unacceptable that the idea that illegal immigrants is a resource is being passed on. Let me ask you two simple questions: what added value have 100,000 illegal immigrants brought to Italy this year? The half million illegal immigrants who arrived in Italy in the last three years, what has brought positive to our country? I'll give you the answer: nothing, zero! Indeed, violence, aggression and degradation in our cities have increased. Italians are fed up with the damage caused by these fake resources. The resources that Italy needs do not come from the boats loaded with illegal immigrants leaving Libya. The real resources of my country are young people, families, working citizens who want a peaceful future without mass immigration. It is in our young people that this Europe must invest, not in illegal immigrants. (The speaker refuses a "blue card" question from Silvia Costa)

name: Emilian Pavel
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Madam President, this report has been one of the ones I have worked on most dearly, because it addresses issues that I consider to be truly essential for our European future: education and citizens' development. Before all the other burning priorities of our Union, I do not think it is possible to talk about real development without having an education and training system that gives Europeans a real chance at a better future. I don't think the new skills agenda in Europe brings anything shocking. This report sets out a number of simple principles and actions. However, they can have an extremely high impact if they are implemented seriously and committed by each Member State. Education and training are, of course, the exclusive competences of each Member State, but I think we can all accept that we have a lot in common. I do not think we have any excuse for not investing in an education conducive to inclusion, which responds to social and economic challenges, which ensures equal access and opportunities for all, regardless of age. I believe that every European must have the right to acquire fundamental skills for the 21st century throughout his or her life. I call on the Member States to focus in their vocational training and education programs on skills that contribute to vocational integration, such as basic skills such as literacy and digital skills, as well as on digital literacy and skills that are relevant to society at large. a more general way. These would be transversal, transferable or non-technical skills such as leadership, social and intercultural skills, managerial and entrepreneurial education. Furthermore, I call on the Member States to implement concrete measures to facilitate the transition of young people from education to work, through ensuring quality and well-paid internships and apprenticeships that provide young people with a set of social and economic rights.I believe that we have an excellent agenda for skills in Europe.My question is: what are we going to do with it?

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, European education and training systems need to adapt to the rapidly changing economic, technological and social environment in order to meet the real needs of citizens and national priorities. Education and lifelong learning face challenges such as high skills, the digital environment, the special needs of people with disabilities, poverty and unemployment. A grid of educational systems and methods without strategic background and ethical principles leads to disaster. Capacity building and maximizing citizens' potential must be achieved at the same time as cultivating morality and virtue. Otherwise, there is a risk that the acquired knowledge will be directed to anti-social or illegal or even extreme activities. The love for the homeland, the family and Christianity, especially for Greece, is above and beyond any other skills and this agenda should focus on these if we want to educate European citizens and not passively adapt them to today. time.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! First of all, I thank the rapporteurs for their work on this report. I believe that it is extremely important to continue developing education and training systems in the European Union, especially in the context of dynamic changes and technological evolution. Colleagues have already said how many millions of Europeans - as confirmed by OECD data - have significant problems with the basic skills of reading, writing and numeracy. For this reason, the solution to this issue should be treated as an absolute priority. It is important to create a pan-European skills forecasting tool that will allow young people to develop as well as identify competences that will prove useful in the future. Today, the ability to navigate in the media and digital world and the ability to think critically are indispensable attributes for adaptation in the contemporary workplace. Thus, teaching entrepreneurship and creativity should be supported from an early age. We know how important it is today to skilfully use digital tools, so bridging the technological gaps in the education system and maintaining funding for the development of education in Europe should be of utmost importance.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, even in your absence, I will immediately reply to what the Hon. Bizzotto, recalling that perhaps he does not know that, for example, in our country half of immigrant women have a degree or a diploma. But I understand that she is not very interested in the subject and she calls them all illegal immigrants. I would like to say, as former chairman of the committee on culture and education and now coordinator of the S & amp; D group, that I am very happy with the good cooperation that has started in this legislature between the committee on culture and education and Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, understanding that the challenge, as shown by the agenda for new European skills, is a cross-cutting challenge that we must face together, including through the ten actions proposed by the agenda. I believe that this is also very important for the most significant recommendations that can be made to Member States to speed up the processes of inclusion of informal skills, in particular to address digital skills applied at all levels of education. But I would like to say that, precisely due to the great obsolescence of the labor market and current skills, a great basic high education is needed, together with the crossing with specific skills and, therefore, combining knowledge, skills and abilities. If there is an imbalance between these elements, we have not understood the challenge of the future.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, in a modern world where old jobs for lower-skilled workers are rapidly disappearing, lifelong learning is a necessity.I am pleased that the rapporteurs recognize that education and training are the responsibility of the Member States, but I agree that cross-border cooperation can be very valuable to us.Since I come from Croatia, where spears are being broken over curriculum reform, and which has not implemented real education reform for decades, I am convinced that at this very moment the experiences of our partners can be of great help to us.The report justifiably emphasizes the importance of teachers, coaches, mentors and other educators as they are the foundation of any reform.Unfortunately, they are often not given the recognition they deserve and do not invest enough in them, and thus deprive children of the opportunity for quality education.If we want our children to be ready for the future, we need to invest more in those who pass on knowledge and skills to them.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Ms Dlabajová and Mr Nekov, for their great work. Our world is changing fast. Education should be the means to empower children and adults alike to become active participants in the transformation of their societies. Learning should focus on the values, attitudes and behaviours which enable individuals to live together in a world of technology, characterised by diversity and pluralism. But at the same time, it should develop the skills demanded by our moral, globalised and digital economy. The new skills agenda was highly needed in order to overcome the security issues existing in the EU. Furthermore, we still need to make qualification systems in Europe comparable, with a focus on qualification levels and learning outcomes. I welcome the support for modernisation on that and adult education. Member States’ private and public companies and institutions should invest more resources.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! Today we talk a lot about the labor market here, but I would like to emphasize that, in my opinion, we cannot shape and perceive the education system as a service system for the labor market. It should be, and it is the other way around: what we do in education systems results in a fair - better or worse - labor market. This is my first point. And the second: because it is education that shapes the labor market, the transversal, soft and key skills, which were discussed in the New Skills Agenda for Europe program, are so important. It is very good that it happened. I am very glad that the key skills will be reviewed, because it is important to properly build the labor market. I would like to say that I see this program as an intervention program. We have a huge problem in Europe when it comes to skills: 40% of employers cannot find workers with the right skills. Over 20% (and sometimes more) of people have problems with reading, writing, understanding, i.e. with basic skills. We have 2 million vacancies and 25 million unemployed, so we have to intervene, and this program is the right way to do so.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union enshrines the right of access to training and learning for all. Training and learning, however, must also subsequently translate into something concrete, that is, in a job that meets expectations. Over 30% of highly skilled young people are in jobs that do not match their skills and aspirations. At the same time, 40% of European employers report that they cannot find people with sufficient skills to grow and innovate. This is the sign of a real short circuit between supply and demand: often the most qualified young people find themselves having to rely exclusively on family resources. If Europe wants to build a future for itself, it must start from here, from strengthening the links between education and employment, with a more flexible, individual and personalized approach, involving all the players in the labor market in the definition of expendable skills and in the connection between these two worlds.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, unemployment affecting the European Union as well as the deregulation of labor relations and the reduction of wages will all be addressed by changing policies. Because it was the policy of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment that has created the huge problems. The reduction of wages is of course due to the creation of a "reserve army" which is refugees and illegal immigrants, who of course most of them work illegally and thus their salaries are reduced. Beyond that, of course, one cannot question the important role that education and training can play in tackling poverty and social exclusion. The main role, of course, must be played by the Member States, but in order to do that, funds are needed, and these funds can be provided by the European Union. At the same time, with education we can contribute to the creation of a democratic society but there must be equal opportunities for access for all those in need of education.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Madam President, the positions developed on the need for young people in Europe to acquire skills to meet the demands of the job are correct. The problem is that theory is far from practical. What is happening is that, indeed, the European Union is providing some funds, some training is being done and at this point all development stops. Young people in Europe need to find work. Unfortunately this is not done or is not done easily. For this reason they are exploited by employers, who force them to work long hours, do not pay them according to their qualifications and skills and education and, many times, threaten them with dismissal, because there are others who waiting to take their place. Tragic victims of these developments are the young people of Greece who, despite their education and abilities, due to the existence of many illegal immigrants who want to work under miserable conditions and with very low salaries, are forced to emigrate many times and outside Europe with all the consequences that arise.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we need to prepare learners of all ages and from all backgrounds, including migrants and refugees, for a fast—changing, complex and hyper—connected world, and for jobs and competences that do not even exist yet. That’s why it is key to ensure that learners are equipped with transferable skills such as media literacy, critical and creative thinking and entrepreneurship. We also want to equip learners with the necessary skills for a more open, sustainable and inclusive society. We therefore need to invest in their social skills, in particular intercultural skills. On top of guaranteeing a minimum level of literacy, numeracy and digital skills for all, there are skills we must invest in for learners to become not only fit for the labour market, but true problem—solvers and responsible and active citizens. In this context, it is key that proper recognition is given to the role of adult learning, informal and non—formal learning.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all those who have spoken in this important debate. With the right skills, people are equipped for quality jobs and can fulfil their potential in the labour market and in society as confident and active citizens. With the right skills, our companies can thrive, invest and innovate, contributing to the virtuous circle of job creation and growth. These are two sides of the same coin: making sure that people can acquire the skills they need to improve their chances for better employment and that they can update these skills to better face job transitions, and equipping Europe to compete and succeed, now and in future, in the global economy. With this report, Parliament has underlined the need to continue our joint efforts to tackle the skills challenge. We welcome your commitment to supporting the implementation of the Skills Agenda, both in Europe and in your home countries.  On 20 November, we will launch the second European Vocational Skills Week. Our message is: ‘Discover your talent!’. We want to improve the attractiveness and image of vocational and educational training. We look forward to working together with you to spread this message at European, national, regional and local levels.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: rapporteur. - Thank you to colleagues for your helpful comments and knowledge. We are talking here about the future, about a new generation of knowledge and skills that will support employment and our competitiveness. We must all have the ambition to educate confident citizens, modern Europeans who are well prepared for life and who will not be afraid to take responsibility for themselves or others. I believe that our report is the first step on this path. Essential needs have already been defined and we know which way to go. What Europe needs is a new set-up for the education system. A system that will respond flexibly to the changes that are inevitable today. Of course, many of you have said that linking education systems to current labor market needs is necessary and, of course, in balance. I would like to reassure my colleague Mara Bizzott that we have been thinking about our young generation when working on this report, and they are our number one priority. I do not understand why my colleagues insult these young people by abusing the debate about their future purely for the political goals of her extreme right, which is also proved by the fact that she is no longer in the Chamber. But in conclusion, I would like to emphasize one thing. The idea that the development of the European labor market is something far removed that does not burn us yet is wrong. Now is the best time to discuss the future, and especially now we need to start acting. Today, not tomorrow, said my favorite, successful businessman and manager Tomáš Baťa. So today, and not tomorrow, let us give the new skills agenda the attention it deserves, and let us not postpone these changes, which we really need to make today.

name: Момчил Неков
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, during the preparation of the report, we had many meetings with Mrs Dlabayova in the European Parliament as well. I had meetings at European and national level with employers who said that horizontal skills were very important, such as teamwork, creativity, critical thinking, creative thinking, etc. This is in one direction. Teachers, on the other hand, also said that they also have challenges with digital skills and need to overcome them. That is why we need to invest first in teachers, not just in building digital infrastructure. Separately, we need to restore the brilliance of vocational education, because, at least in my country, vocational education is considered to be the worst for children. In this case, in order to overcome exactly this phenomenon, we must rely on early career guidance. This means that from an early age children are taken to factories for various productions, to use new technologies, to see how these new technologies are made, in order to acquire this desire and then to enroll in vocational education. As Ms. Dlabayova said, now we are building the future, but we really do not know in 10 - 20 years what will be the professions of the future. From this point of view, we need to build more than one system of education, we need to build personalities and put people at the center not only within the education system. We must strive for lifelong learning and lifelong learning, and to make a very clear distinction between facts and opinions.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place today, September 14, 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- In the age of globalization and especially of digitalisation and very rapid technological progress, education and training systems in Europe must certainly be updated.For this reason, the initiative has been awaited for some time, and it has finally come.The report broadens the concept of competences not by restricting the field to those immediately "verifiable", but by including different aspects.We move from emphasizing the entrepreneurial spirit and creativity to condemning the cutting of funds for education.The encouragement present in the agenda to make use of the flexibility of work, which, in the absence of adequate safeguards, is too often conjugated as precariousness is not equally appreciable;as well as references to the European semester system.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: in writing. - In the EU, as many as one-fourth of the population do not have the skills needed for the job they perform, and as many as 40% of employers are unable to find employees with appropriate qualifications. As many as 70 million people in the EU do not have basic literacy and numeracy skills. This means that the actions taken so far have not brought the expected results. The main reasons for this can be indicated. First, no one has learned from the programs already in progress. Second, we have seen spending on education and training fall in recent years. In 2010–2014, they fell by as much as 2.5% in the entire EU. Therefore, first of all, we should call on the Commission to follow the implementation of existing programs and learn from the mistakes made, and to the governments of the Member States not to seek savings in this sensitive segment of social policy. In the new skills agenda, we must focus, among other things, on meeting current labor market needs. Future-oriented action is needed and in-depth reflection on what to do to meet these needs in the coming decades. The effective implementation of new training and education systems takes time, so the activities currently undertaken should be focused on forecasted needs, not on those that exist today.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - Many elements of the European Parliament's report on new skills development in Europe support the Orbán government's education policy. Developments related to e-skills, or the modernization of vocational training systems, the introduction of dual training have all been given special emphasis in Hungary since 2010. Years ago, the Hungarian government began to develop and implement comprehensive national strategies for digital skills and e-skills developments. At present, HUF 270 billion of EU support is available in the period 2014–2020, of which only HUF 125 billion is spent by the government on infrastructure development. This primarily means new schools and the renovation of existing ones with a radically renewable set of educational tools. The remainder will be spent on content development, such as the development of digital curricula and the new National Core Curriculum (NAT). Significant sums are also being spent on the digital development of schools outside the central region, the range of mobile devices in schools is expanding, and 50,000 teachers can take part in in-service training aimed at using new content and tools. At the same time, the left-wing factions tabled an amendment at the end, vaguely referring to the requirements for migrants, which could be interpreted in a number of ways, including support for illegal immigrants, which was unanimously opposed by the Hungarian People's Party. In view of all this, I abstained at the end of the vote on the adoption of the entire document, as a good professional report was basically overwritten politically and irresponsibly.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: in writing. - In a knowledge society, education is a key aspect of being active in life. High-quality education is essential to equip young people with the knowledge, attitudes, skills and attitudes towards the world that will help them understand and change the world. Education has a huge impact on many areas of economic and social life, so we need a holistic approach to education and policies that support high-quality education at all levels. Continuous access to education throughout life is particularly important for the most disadvantaged and people with disabilities. I also pay particular attention to the status, working conditions, remuneration, qualifications and skills of teachers, trainers, mentors and educators. The delivery of the European Skills Agenda depends on the quality of education, guaranteed by teachers. Education systems should attract the best staff who should enjoy the support of parents and the local community and be provided with permanent opportunities for professional development.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - On September 14, 2017, the European Parliament supported a series of wishful thinking in the area of ​​skills. On the menu, catalogs of recycled measures and an old tune dear to Brussels: "Newcomers bring with them new skills". In truth, beyond the "Molenbeek" effect, our future does not depend on "non-Europeans". The employment rate of "non-Europeans" was only 51% in France in 2016, or one in two "lazy" (sic Macron). Obviously these new skills are not transferable. The Commission’s third-country national profiling tool is not even available in languages ​​spoken by all migrants. The waste of 155 billion euros from the European Social Fund (ESF) is demonstrated: out of 30 million participants, 21 million have not found a job after their "training". Revitalizing Europe will require European preference and the launch of new industries. As proof, Airbus was born out of cooperation between states (Germany, France, Great Britain) in May 1967, outside the European Union and without the intervention of the Brussels Commission.

name: Marek Plura (PPE)
text: in writing.- I sincerely congratulate the rapporteurs on preparing an interesting and comprehensive report.I agree with them that there is a need for entrepreneurship education starting from primary school.As I have emphasized many times (including in my own report on skills strategies to combat youth unemployment), entrepreneurship is also about being empowered and creative.These skills help in professional and social life, which is why I consider developing them crucial.I also support the rapporteurs' call for an inclusive approach to the development of education and training strategies.I believe that thanks to this approach, disability will cease to be a barrier to developing potential and being an active entrepreneur, employee, citizen.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. - In the European Union, 66 million people aged 25 to 64 have not gone beyond lower secondary education. Behind these startling figures, there are so many people who often find themselves in a difficult situation, especially financially; some live a form of social exclusion on a daily basis. The new skills strategy for Europe is primarily aimed at these people. Every journey, every experience has value! We must recognize the achievements in all other forms of learning (formal, but also non-formal and informal) and also promote lifelong learning. The European Union must build bridges between people and between different policies. Because only a global approach, combining education, training, employment, youth, health and social emancipation, will be beneficial for all Europeans.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The new skills agenda is one of the key tools for achieving the goals of social cohesion and job creation and growth, addressing two urgent challenges facing the European Union: the lack of skills relevant to the labor market and the creation of educational programs for all social categories. Among the ten actions proposed by the Commission in the agenda for the coming years, I believe that the recommendations on key competences are of strategic importance to the EU. In order to respond to the economic and social transformations that have taken place over the last decade, there is an urgent need for a common approach to a core set of skills to work and live in the 21st century. In this regard, a priority will be the digital sector, where we need a strategy to equip European citizens with the right digital skills. As a member of the TRAN Commission, however, I remain convinced that the European Skills Strategy needs to pay more attention to tourism. This can be one of the sectors in which to fight youth unemployment and relaunch the EU economy. That is why I support the establishment of a Tourism Academy, with the help of which young Europeans have the chance not only to have a job, but to start a successful career.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing.- The new Skills Agenda for Europe is a long-awaited initiative that we urgently need in this period.Not only in my country, but throughout the EU, there is a gap between European education systems and the economic and social environment.The labor market is dynamic and the education system is often rigid.It is therefore essential to move towards a pan-European tool for forecasting skills needs.Starting the economy is necessary, just as a good and skilled workforce is necessary.I therefore support this report, as I believe it is important to go beyond relevant professional skills and to focus on those aspects of education that can foster entrepreneurship and creativity, enable people to think critically, make informed decisions and participate fully indemocratic and social life.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on NordStream 2 (2017/2832 (RSP)).

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to deliver, on behalf of the Commission, a statement on the Nord Stream 2 project. I know that this continues to be a subject to which many of you attach a high importance and which we have discussed already a number of times. Today I would like to update you on what has happened with regard to this file since the last time the Commission stood before you nearly a year ago. As you know, our stance on this project derives directly from the Energy Union objectives and in particular from our desire to enhance energy security through creating a well-diversified, secure and competitive gas market. We do not see that, if built, the Nord Stream 2 project would contribute to these objectives, essentially for two reasons. First, because it will not contribute to diversification, as it will give access neither to a new source nor to a new route of gas supply. In this it is different from Nord Stream 1. Second, we project gas demand to decline from today’s level of 460 billion cubic metres to somewhere between 350 and 410 billion cubic metres by 2030. Against falling domestic production and a roughly stable level of imports, the Commission sees no need for a new infrastructure of the magnitude of Nord Stream 2. A massive addition of 55 billion cubic metre import capacity through Nord Stream 2 could rather lead to further concentration and allow Gazprom to further strengthen its position on the European Union gas market. I know that these concerns relating to the impact of the project on the Energy Union objectives are shared by many Members of this House. But beyond these political considerations, in the past exchanges with Vice—President Šefčovič and myself, many of you have also expressed the more specific concern that a project of such magnitude and with such an impact on our internal gas market could not, and should not, be developed outside the EU’s legal framework. Allow me to update you on the steps that the Commission has recently taken to address this specific issue. First, we consider that it cannot be in the European Union’s interests that the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, if built, would be operated in a legal void or only according to third-country law. Second, when it comes to the application of our internal market rules, we have to take into account that the Nord Stream 2 pipeline is in a specific legal situation, different from other projects. The gas pipeline entry point lies in a third country, while the exit point is on European Union territory, and the pipeline passes under the sea, including through European Union Member States’ territorial waters. Clearly, Union rules cannot be made directly binding within the jurisdiction of third countries. Moreover, the Third Gas Directive does not explicitly include a specific framework for such situations. Therefore, the Commission is of the view that a specific legal regime is needed. The starting point for such a specific legal regime should be the core principles of international and European Union energy law. These principles include a certain degree of third-party access, a degree of separation between supply and transmission, non-discrimination in tariff-setting and transparency. In this spirit, on 9 June the Commission adopted a recommendation to the Council requesting a mandate to negotiate with the Russian Federation an agreement on the operation of the pipeline. Our aim is to ensure that a project of this scale, which impacts the internal market and security of supply, is operated according to the main principles of international and European Union energy rules. We have transmitted this recommendation to the Council and also to the European Parliament. Discussions on the mandate have started in the Council. Overall, a majority of Member States have welcomed the Commission proposal of a mandate. Three different approaches to the Mandate can be distinguished at this stage in the Council. First, there is a significant number of Member States which are clearly in favour of the Mandate. Second, there is a group of Member States who are rather neutral towards the idea and have not yet made their view known. Finally, only a few Member States are at this stage against the Mandate, albeit for different reasons: either because they see it as unnecessary or, on the other hand, because they consider it not sufficiently ambitious. Furthermore, the Council’s Legal Service has been requested to provide an opinion, and the Presidency is now waiting for this opinion before continuing the discussions. As I said, a copy of the mandate has been sent to the European Parliament. As required by the Treaty, if the Council agrees to authorise negotiations, then the Commission will keep the European Parliament fully informed at all stages of the negotiation and upon the conclusion of an agreement. Finally, I will say that the Commission is also working on a proposal to clarify the regulatory framework for pipelines coming from third countries. This is in any event without prejudice to the Mandate for Nord Stream 2.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! First of all, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the clear and strong positioning that he has just undertaken, but also for involving the European Parliament. There are two aspects that we need to see. One aspect is the energy issue. As the European Union, we have clear goals on the energy issue: we want diversification, we want to tie up more resources so that we can become more independent. NordStream 2 doesn't lead to more diversification, it leads to more dependency. That is why the first goal has not been achieved with this project. The second principle is our legal principles, which the Commissioner referred to, which must be enforced. And of course the question arises in a very practical way - and that brings me to my second point: if the project, as the Commissioner said, is not necessary for Europe's security of supply, if the pipelines are not necessary, then why is so much money going on issued? And that brings us to politics. Then we know that it is not an economic but a political project. The best proof of this is the commitment of Gerhard Schröder and many other politicians on the relevant supervisory boards, and the question of political entanglement also arises. Gerhard Schröder will not be employed there because he has good economic experience, but because he has good political contacts. In this respect, it is important to make it clear that this is a political project. We know that we have many difficult questions with Russia: Georgia, Ukraine, Syria. Russia is on the wrong track, using the military to achieve its political goals. That is why we must not do unnecessary further business, but must show clarity. One final thought, Madam President: Germany, as the country that is most affected by the project, should now be a clear sign the EU partnership.That means: The mandate that the Commissioner has presented must be supported by Germany so that it becomes clear that we all want a European solution together.

name: Jeppe Kofod
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, it is very clear that Nord Stream 2 is directly against both the spirit and the objective of our energy Union. It is clear for many reasons; the Commissioner mentioned it himself. First of all, we will increase our dependence on the reliable supply of energy if the Nord Stream 2 is built. Secondly, we will also increase our dependence on fossil fuel in Europe if Nord Stream 2 is built, while at the same time we are trying to make a climate and energy Union in which we decarbonise our energy system. Thirdly, we will also expose ourselves to pressure from external partners, so it is also a security matter for Europeans. Russia will now have a direct or indirect means of pressuring Member States in Europe, and it is clear that we cannot let that happen. Therefore, it is high time that the Commission and Council clearly say ‘no’ to Nord Stream 2, because it is going against our solidarity and our aims in Europe.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! The Nord Stream II project has no market justification. It is not in line with European law, in particular with the Third Energy Package. It is also at odds with the fundamental European values ​​which the Commission so often refers to. It will have a disastrous effect on diversification in Central and Eastern Europe. Nevertheless, the implementation of this project has still not been abandoned. Perhaps because he enjoys enormous political support not only in Russia, as Mr. Weber said. The symbol of this state of affairs is indeed Gerhard Schroeder, recently appointed director in Russia's Rosneft, still exerting an influence on Germany and Europe. I would also like to add that Chancellor Angela Merkel, unfortunately, also supported this project. The Commission should therefore be more bold and resolute - also with regard to those anti-European projects involving enterprises of the strongest member states and which are supported by their political and economic elites.

name: Morten Helveg Petersen
text: for the ALDE Group. - Madam President! Nord Stream 2 will go through Danish waters if it turns into anything, and so far the line has been treated as an issue of an environmental technical nature. But that pipeline is geopolitics from the very top shelf: it is security policy, it is environmental policy, it is climate policy and much more. And right now, when we in the EU are creating the framework for our energy union, which we all sit and work with every single day, yes, the ambition is precisely to ensure a fluid internal market for energy. But the idea for the Energy Union was born out of a desire to make Europe independent of Putin's gas and the sheikhs' oil. So right now we are making sanctions against Russia with one hand and then we will make new big deals with them with the other hand. It does not work, and therefore we are deeply critical of Nord Stream! Europe must go in the completely opposite direction than the fossil that Putin's gas and Nord Stream 2 represent. That is why we are pleased that the Commission is now stepping in and that the Council of Ministers is getting into the matter, which is badly needed so that we can stop this project.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, a new millionaire interconnection of 9.5 billion euros to import more gas, although its demand is decreasing; 1,200 kilometers of underwater gas pipeline, with a rather serious environmental effect on the surroundings. But today there is more talk of geopolitics than energy. Well, behind this project there are many interests: those of Gazprom, those of Wintershall, NG, Shell, and also those of the German and Russian elites. And, despite the fact that this Tuesday we voted on the Commission's priority report for the security of gas supply, today I see here, Commissioner, a rather soft position - I would say - with the German government and with the gas lobbies , with whom you meet regularly. I thought that when someone opposed the plans of the European Commission, they would be stepped on and sanctioned, as they already did with Greece. In short, we do not want another gas pipeline in the Baltic Sea, nor a European Commission with double standards towards member countries.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I am very grateful to you for the clarity of your speech, Commissioner Cañete. And I am grateful that you are finding that you are not only speaking on your own behalf but are also taking this position here on behalf of the Commission. I think it is an important fact that we have a very clear position on this. I agree with almost everything that the speakers have said so far. In particular with you, Mr Weber, and only Mr Krasnodębski, I would like to contradict one point: if you talk about the role of Gerhard Schröder, I am happy to admit that I too regard this role as shameful. As far as the role of the current Chancellor is concerned: I see it a little differently, and here I am with you, Mr Weber. You said: This is not just a commercial business - I agree with you. So far, however, the Chancellor has tried to hide behind the argument that it is only an economic deal in order not to have to show clear political colors. And when you say that Germany should send a clear signal to the EU partnership and make it clear that Germany is not blocking this mandate, but supporting it, I am back with you, but we will have to drill a lot together in Berlin to get the votes Also in your party, which has so far publicly criticized this, finally penetrate so far that the Chancellor also says a clear word. I recently visited Mukran. I was on site in Stralsund and spoke to the affected farmers and the environmental associations and the approval authorities. One tries to create facts on site. Let us work together to ensure that this mandate comes about and that our country supports it. (The speaker agrees to post a question the "blue card" procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- I totally agree not only with what you said, but also with what your colleagues said.And with what the Commissioner said.But don't you think that we MEPs should know clearly which states are opposed?(The Commissioner said that there are opposing states.) And we, as MEPs, should go to the national parliaments, obviously, to the opposing states, and ask for an explanation because yes, we should not be dependent on gas.Russian.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, as far as I am informed, there are three governments that have expressed reservations: the German Government, the Austrian Government and the Dutch Government. Mostly, it hinges on the position of the Germans. I think what some of us have said is very clear: we want the German Government to change its position. One coalition partner in our national government is very much in favour of this project – the Social Democrats. We Greens are not, and the CDU – as a party and a partner in government – has not taken a very clear position, and a new step is needed.

name: Rolandas Paksas
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mr President, colleagues. Recently politicized energy issues can only mean one thing: the rise in energy prices. That politicization also demonstrates that because of a politician’s inability to agree and find points of contact, society will always be forced to pay more for gas, electricity, or oil products. Nord Stream did not appear yesterday or the day before yesterday. It is clear that building the Great Wall of China in Europe, closing the airspace or fencing underwater areas with nets will not work. Therefore, today I would suggest abandoning low value-added politics. Let us look at this project as useful as economic, looking for economic benefits not political dividends. In an economy, cheaper energy resources always mean lower production costs. The ability to reduce costs may be one of the preconditions for intensifying the significant slowdown in economic growth in European countries after the crisis, both in terms of higher exports and new jobs.

name: Michał Marusik
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President! We can see that a project like Nordstream is a great engineering venture, but we are focusing more on other aspects of it - the business aspects are the most visible. And here we focus on even more important aspects, that is, the political aspects, the possibility of political influence, and therefore the use of political pressure or even political blackmail using such a serious tool as the transfer of hydrocarbons. I would like to highlight one more aspect that we are omitting here. Well, it is an extremely important symbolic aspect. This shows what changes are taking place in European politics. Well, a kind of Orwellian world is being built, where all countries are equal, but some countries are more equal. We say many beautiful words here, and real politics is where silence persists. There is silence about the process that can be seen on the Nordstream pipeline: all these aspects of political influence are in the hands of Russia and Germany, because the whole chain of hydrocarbon supplies and distribution will be in the hands of Germany and Russia, and they will have the tools to implement their own policy by methods of blackmail and pressure. And we can't pretend we don't see it.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Madam President, it is easy to see that the United States of America is behind your objections to the expansion of the NordStream pipeline. You say that we need to differentiate the sources from which the Union supplies natural gas. This pipeline does not prevent the exploitation of other deposits that have been discovered, some of which in fact in countries of the Union, such as Greece and Cyprus. On the contrary, it is Turkey that is trying in every way to prevent mining. As for Russia, it is the Union that supports the aggressive policy of the Americans against it. The Union funded and organized the coup in Ukraine that overthrew its legitimately elected government. It is the Union that backed the graphic Saakashvili against Russia. On the contrary, when the Union imposed sanctions on Russia at the request of the Americans, the supply of natural gas did not stop for an hour, demonstrating how unfounded energy security rhetoric is. The only way that benefits all parties and ensures stability on our continent is that of cooperation and honest partnership between Russia and the rest of Europe. (The speaker declined a question with a blue card by Michaela Šojdrova)

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Madam President! We are indeed debating an issue that is extremely important, extremely - I would say - hot, topical and controversial. I share the position of the Commissioner, which was also confirmed by Mr Weber, which I welcome. Firstly, this investment does not increase the diversification of gas supply sources, on the contrary - it makes us more dependent on one source of supply, and creating facts in the form of a multi-billion investment makes this dependence permanent or may be permanent. Secondly, possibly lower costs were mentioned. Let us remember that in a situation of market dominance, costs and their level are never guaranteed. There was no voice here on ecology, which is also extremely important. I would like to add that I share the views that the project is political. Political not because of Gerhard Schröder, but political in a larger dimension: political because of the omission of states and voices that raise objections to this project. Finally, there is no clear separation between functions, infrastructure management and supplier. For this reason, the mandate should lead us not to encourage the implementation of this project.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! We have already heard a lot about NordStream 2 today that, for example, NordStream 1 is underutilized, that our eastern neighbors feel more and more vulnerable to blackmail - we heard that too - and that Germany is becoming more and more dependent on Russian gas. But I would like to point out that this is actually unacceptable not only for the Poles, that a veritable scandal can be recognized in this context: A few weeks after Gerhard Schröder, as Chancellor of the then government, was so amazingly committed to the NordStream-1 When the project started, he was hired by President Putin. MEPs regularly complain - especially in this Parliament - that when politicians leave their offices, they shortly afterwards take on other offices in business, especially German politicians. And that is why I think it is absolutely necessary that not only the Poles, but also the German politicians criticize this scandal in connection with this project. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Thank you very much for the opportunity, honorable Member.You mentioned the international dimensions of this whole issue, at least several such aspects.I would like to ask you if you do not think that the number of countries affected by this project could be included in this list, or that Ukraine could be included, given that a pipeline through Ukraine would be replaced by this Nord Stream line 2, thusUkrainians could easily be left without gas.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- (The speaker speaks without a microphone.)… Make that I just said that the neighbors to the east also feel that they can be blackmailed, and that of course includes Ukraine.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: - Madam President! It is clear that one can see this as a business transaction if it is not even one's own country that Russian interests fly into in exercises to secure their gas deliveries to Europe. We already have a management. NOC is now building another line that risks, first of all, going against all our climate and energy work that we are doing. The biggest team package we have right now is the Clean Energy for All Europeans package. This goes completely beyond the ambition of it. Secondly, two major military exercises are currently taking place in the Baltic Sea. One based in Sweden, the other based on Russian interests. Let us say that this is escalating, let us say that the intensity of the conflict between the West and Russia is increasing. What will Russia do then? Well, guaranteed to violate Swedish water and Swedish airspace because you want to guarantee that you can supply Europe with gas. No question is so simple that it would just be a business transaction. Here we have a responsibility for all security in Europe, for the climate, for energy. We in Parliament can put our foot down and demand clearer action. This project should have been stopped a long time ago.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Thank you, Commissioner, for taking part in the discussion again. Dear colleagues, we actually had three such discussions in the European Parliament. The conclusion is similar, as you can see, to what was before. The vast majority of the European Parliament is against the Nordstream 2 project, because it does not meet the conditions and principles of the Energy Union and there can be no derogations or financial support for it. The Council is now due to decide on the mandate, but it is not known how and how to vote it. After obtaining the mandate, the European Commission will possibly start negotiations, but this negotiating mandate, and above all the results of the negotiations, must be approved by the European Parliament in an appropriate procedure - this is a very complicated matter. It would be clear to us if this mandate said that up to the border of a third country, across the Baltic, this pipeline must comply with European Union law, and especially with the Third Energy Package.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, during the current parliamentary term many hopes have been placed on the Energy Union, which aims to strengthen the Union's energy security and ensure the functioning of the internal energy market. In this context the discussion on NordStream 2 is of crucial importance. If the doubling of the pipeline were to go through, 80% of Russian gas to Europe would reach only one point, Germany, risking further worsening the situation, damaging other countries and increasing dependence on fossil fuels. NordStream 2, therefore, clearly goes against the interests of the European Union for the diversification of energy supply, because it risks greatly increasing the European Union's dependence on Russian gas and contradicts the European objectives in terms of energy security, especially for the partner countries of Eastern Europe. The Commission must act in all appropriate fora to put an end to the implementation of this project - which some political lobbies seem happy with - which would nullify the design of the European Union, a flagship project of the Juncker administration.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! In politics in general, and in the Nord Stream II case in particular, one must distinguish between words and actions. The construction of Nord Stream II should be stopped immediately. This project will actually compromise our sanctions against Russia. It compromises our eastern policy. Moreover, it must be recalled that it also compromises actions that have been endorsed by the European Commission, such as the Minsk agreements. The Nord Stream II project is actively supported, and its party is Germany, a state that, in a sense, on behalf of the European Union - because with the support of the Commission - concluded Minsk agreements. Let us remember what several colleagues said, for example Mr. Tibor Szanyi: Nord Stream I was turned against Poland and the Baltic states, Nord Stream II is a project directed primarily against Ukraine. If we take our words seriously, Nord Stream II should be included in the sanctions policy as soon as possible.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, we in the Czech Republic certainly also want to diversify energy sources, but this must be in line with the spirit and objectives on which our European Union is built. It is clear that this project is not in line with these objectives. It threatens our energy security. It increases dependence on Russia and threatens Ukraine, and in fact denies the sanctions we have adopted in connection with Russia's aggression in eastern Ukraine. In its consequences, it also goes against the Paris Climate Agreement. I think we need to make it clear here who is behind this project. To me, surprisingly, the former German Chancellor, who was very pro-European and now works in Russia's salary. Thank you very much for the opinion presented by the Commissioner, because it is a clear position of the Commission with a clear explanation. A new government will be established in the Czech Republic after the October elections, and I am very much interested in what position NordStream 2 will take on this very topic.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Madam President, the creation of a market for gas supply with good dispersion and competition is a matter of security and stability strategy for the European Union. Mr Juncker explained it correctly yesterday and Commissioner Cañete explained it very correctly today. The European Union's trade and agreements are a tool through which we must export our own standards and, I add, it is a tool through which we must seek to export our own values. We clarify, however, that the decision on this project should be based on European criteria which are legal, political and strategic. But this debate, Commissioner, raises another issue. The need for other sources of supply such as in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus, in cooperation with both Egypt and Israel. Continue on the same line.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete for his efforts, which are a very hopeful sign. But I would like to say that it is not business as usual: in fact, hesitations and ambiguity about this project are going to undermine the very foundations of this Union – solidarity, energy independence and diversification. The question is: who benefits? Most of all, Russia will benefit from it. Russia, which is going to strengthen its military control just at this moment in the Baltic Sea, and also some German big interests. My message to the German Social Democrats is to stop supporting this project, because it is clear that there is a big conflict between realpolitik and EU solidarity. We need legal clarity and unity about this as soon as possible.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I believe that the possible implementation or construction of this new planned pipeline will absolutely jeopardize all existing and more or less well-functioning supply chains.It would cover the current structure of Europe's gas supply to such an extent that it completely contradicts all the policies we have developed so far, but at the same time all the objectives of the Energy Union.I think, and here I would like to give the Commission maximum support, and I see that all my colleagues here have done this in order to fulfill their mandate through a completely transparent practice.I believe that the European public has a particular interest in the conduct of Europe here, and I think that it would help a great deal to build a Europe of citizens, so that the Commission could also represent the unity that emerges here in Parliament in a worthy way.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the Members of this Parliament who have participated in the debate, because they have confirmed the importance that this House, and all its Members, attaches to the security of supply of gas. Let me tell you that since I took office my main concern has been to make sure that every single country had access to three different sources of supply and was not dependent on a single supply.  That has been the focus of our activity. We have thus supported the southern corridor to bring gas from Azerbaijan. That is why we delivered an LNG gas strategy to eliminate dependence on Russian gas and have other possibilities in addition to imports of LNG from a lot of countries in which there is an abundant production of gas, and that is why we are also supporting the EastMed gas pipeline which will bring gas from Cyprus, Egypt, Israel, from the Leviathan and from Zohr gas fields, to the European Union as it is fundamental to have another one. That is also why we want to finish all the interconnectors, even those in the Iberian Peninsula, the MidCat. We will connect the Iberian Peninsula with the Central European gas network in order to have more security of supply.  Our guideline has been to have diversification of sources and to support those gas pipelines which are really useful for security of supply, and not give support to pipelines like Nord Stream 2 which can never become a project of common interest because it does not increase our security of supply and it also creates problems for dominant positions in the market in the end. That is the first thing. What is the problem? The problem is that if we could apply European Union legislation directly we would have done so, but our legislation has some problems and that is why we are doing two things now. Firstly, asking for a mandate so that the Council allows the Commission to negotiate with the Russian Federation in order to apply all the principles of our current legislation. And secondly, we are changing our legislation to prevent this from happening in the future. So we will do two things – legislative change and a mandate.
