I very much appreciate the words of Mr Weber when he said that the German Government should also support the mandate because we need the Commission to be in a strong position to negotiate not only application of the principles of the European Union, but also to take into account the situation of Ukraine because the Commission position is also that Nord Stream 2 will have a negative impact on the existing transit routes to the European Union, including via Ukraine.  As a result, the mandate also raises the issue of the possible impact of the pipeline on gas transit via Ukraine and on European Union security of supply, and how such impact will be mitigated. Because we consider Ukraine a stable and reliable transit route and we will continue our support to ensure that Ukraine remains an important transit route, including after 2020.  You can be sure that the Commission is waiting for the Council to decide on the mandate. Any support from the members of parliament within national governments in order to have support will be very welcome and we hope that the Council decides soon and the Commission comes to negotiations. In the meanwhile, we would propose a legislative reform to make very clear that our gas supply regulations are applied in cases like Nord Stream 2 in the future.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: in writing. - The decision to build the Nord Stream gas pipeline, taken in 2005, was a significant breach of the principle of solidarity in force in the EU. The construction of new lines poses a threat to the energy security of the countries in the region, and above all to Ukraine attacked by the Russian Federation, making it more vulnerable to Russian energy blackmail. In its positions and actions, the European Commission has repeatedly supported the Russian energy giant Gazprom rather than its European partners. The decision-making process was accompanied by a whole series of lobbying activities. Recent publications indicate that they were also illegal. Danish investigative journalist Jens Høvsgaard alleges that the Kremlin and Gazprom, led by Russian President Vladimir Putin and former Stasi and KGB agents, bribed and blackmailed Western politicians and ministerial officials in Germany, Sweden, Denmark and Finland. I suspect that similar actions have been and are also applied to officials in Brussels. The task of the President of the Commission is to ensure the transparency of procedures and the independence of the decision-making process. Unfortunately, I have significant concerns about this. I would like to remind you that at every stage, starting with the EP vote in 2005, I was against these investments, pointing to the risks associated with them.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing. - As the discussion during the plenary session clearly showed, Nord Stream2 is unanimously criticized by most political groups of the European Parliament as a purely political project that divides Europe and is dangerous from the point of view of EU security. I also believe that the implementation of this project can be perceived as hypocrisy. On the one hand, we are imposing sanctions on Russia in response to the illegal annexation of Crimea and the deliberate destabilization of Ukraine, on the other hand, it does not prevent the promotion of a project that not only undermines EU solidarity and is clearly contrary to the interests and security of many member states, but it also gives Russia great business potential and an opportunity to develop its gas market. Therefore, I call on the Member States to give a strong mandate to negotiate with Russia so that Nord Stream2 is covered by the rules of the Third Energy Package. I am pleased with the announcement by Commissioner Cañete and President Juncker that the European Commission will propose a new legal regime for gas pipelines like Nord Stream2 to ensure that they automatically fall under the Third Package rules.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: in writing.- There is a huge disproportion between Russia's technical export capabilities and the amount of gas imported by European countries.Even in the record year of 2016, only 67% of the Russian transmission infrastructure was used - so there were approximately 100 billion cubic meters of reserve space left.This shows that the current capacity of all corridors far exceeds the demand in Europe.In this context, it can be seen that the construction of Nord Stream 2 has no market justification, but is a geopolitical project of Vladimir Putin.The Nord Stream 2 project is not consistent with the EU energy policy in the natural gas sector, which emphasizes the development of well-functioning gas markets through increased diversification of supply sources and infrastructure integration.Perhaps it is worth repeating that, contrary to what some do, diversification means more gas from different directions, not more pipelines from Russia.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Nord Stream 2 project is like a test of the effectiveness of European Energy Union solidarity. The project clearly runs counter to the objectives of the European Union's energy, security and neighborhood policy, but, as we can see, it is still difficult to reconcile a common position between the Member States. There is no debate that the Nord Stream 2 project is political, so the European Union's decision cannot be based solely on economic assessments. Given that the South Stream project has been suspended under the EU's energy security strategy due to its non-compliance with EU law, we must ensure that the project that replaces it does not escape EU law. The European Parliament has repeatedly called on the Commission to take concrete action on Nord Stream 2, and I very much welcome the Commission's initiative to present a proposal for common rules for gas pipelines entering the European single gas market and a recommendation to the Council principles of operation of the pipeline project. This clearly shows that there is a legal vacuum that must be filled before any pipeline directly to the European Union market can be built. It is important to note that until the negotiations with Russia on Nord Stream 2 are completed, the project cannot continue.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – When it comes to NordStream 2, Germany unfortunately places the short-term interests of its industry above those of its EU partners, above the EU’s Energy Union, and in the long run above the interests of its own citizens. I should not need to reiterate the examples which demonstrate that Russia is not a reliable partner and doesn’t hesitate to wield energy as a weapon. Earlier this week we adopted, with a large majority, Jerzy Buzek’s report on security of gas supply, which introduces a solidarity mechanism between Member States in cases of gas-shortage emergencies. Yet at the same time Germany is busy undermining all these efforts put into the Energy Union by increasing its dependence on Russian gas. This will have disastrous consequences for Ukraine right now, but in the long-term German and EU citizens will also be subjected to the Kremlin’s whims. Furthermore, the fact that the European part of NordStream 2 is built by European companies cements our lock-in, and will lead to stranded assets in the event of the supply ceasing. Before that, Russia will be able to blackmail us, knowing that we need to keep buying to make up for the sunk costs of the new pipeline.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Cambodia: in particular the case of Kem Sokha (2017/2829 (RSP)).

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Author. - Madam President! Since the local elections in June there have been serious backslides in terms of human rights protection and the democratization process in Cambodia. The situation escalated in August with the arrest of the opposition leader Kem Sokha and attacks against independent media and civil society. These developments must be seen against the background of the upcoming elections in July 2018. It is to be feared that the situation will get worse. Without greater international pressure and resistance, the Cambodian government will soon no longer have any tolerance for critical opinions, for democratic debates and for people who defend their fundamental rights. The EU must address the serious human rights violations consistently and with great attention. The EU supports the Cambodian government through trade benefits. If the repression continues, the EU will need to rethink its trade relations with Cambodia.

name: David Martin
text: author. – Madam President, sadly in recent months we have seen a serious deterioration in human rights in the South—East Asia region, reflected by the fact that we have three urgencies on these countries in this session.  Cambodia sadly is no exception. Given Cambodia’s tragic recent past, it is particularly concerning to see fundamental values such as democracy, the rule of law and freedom of expression all under attack in that country. I urge the Cambodians to release political prisoners, to ensure that political parties – and the opposition in particular – have space to campaign and operate in advance of the 2018 elections in that country, in the hope that we can have fair and free elections in Cambodia. We should remind Cambodia that we are a significant partner of theirs. We are giving them EUR 400 million between 2014 and 2020. We give them trade preferences. We do that because we are a community of values who wish to promote values in that country, and I hope they will respect that.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author. - Madam President, Cambodia is one of those countries for which this European Parliament regularly denounces violations of human rights. Rightly so, because things are going very badly there, we have already said that. Yet, attached to the indivisibility of human rights, I would like us to denounce all violations of human rights as firmly and have the same concern for economic and social rights as for civil rights and policies. In Cambodia, on a bed of corruption, land grabbing is wreaking havoc and multinationals, especially Europeans, are having a blast: 56% of land grabbed and 830,000 people affected. The International Criminal Court has been seized. This is causing huge displacement and deepening misery in a part of the world that does not need it. The case of Tep Vanny is a fine example of the repression that weighs on those who denounce all this. Fighting the root causes of migration is also that, especially in this region of the world most affected by the displacement of populations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: Author. - Mr President, the political climate in Cambodia is deteriorating. Prosecution against the opposition and against activists and the media is on the agenda. We also have arbitrary convictions. Therefore, what is happening is unacceptable and even worsens when we have public statements of the Prime Minister in pending trials and in this way we consider that there is interference in the issues of Justice. Arrests must therefore stop, the political system must function effectively, the government must guarantee the rule of law, freedom of association and the free operation of the media. At the same time, land grabbing must stop. 56% of the land has been effectively confiscated, confiscated, seized. Grabbing of course we have in too many countries and it is unacceptable. The European Union must therefore send a message to Cambodia. The preferential trade agreement with Cambodia cannot continue, these privileges cannot exist and, on the other hand, Cambodia cannot respect human rights.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: author. – Mr President, first of all let me express my warmest greetings to the Cambodian opposition delegation, which is today here with us in the Chamber. I wish to thank you personally for your fight for pluralism and democracy in Cambodia for so many years. What is going on in Cambodia recently makes us increasingly concerned. Instead of seizing an opportunity that is given by the upcoming elections in 2018, instead of choosing a path of reconciliation, respect for human dignity and basic rights, and instead of taking measures to reduce corruption and poverty, we observe repressions against the independent media, civil society and opposition. All this must be stopped immediately. Kem Sokha and other political prisoners must be instantly released, and Sam Rainsy unconditionally pardoned. After decades and decades of enormous suffering, there is so much to do for enduring peace, real reconciliation and better lives in Cambodia. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – I just want to ask my colleague from Lithuania, Mr Petras Auštrevičius, if he agrees with the fact that the EU could send an official mission next year to the election of Cambodia, as we have been always giving money to this country to improve their political situation.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – This is a very current issue. Indeed, we had no observation mission in the recent municipal elections, but for the general elections in 2018 I hope that, with the close cooperation of the external service and our delegation support in Phnom Penh, we will be present observing these elections in order to ensure, as much as possible, transparency and accountability.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. – Mr President, I would like to say to the High Representative that I join my colleague Petras Auštrevičius in supporting his view on the observation mission and greeting the Cambodian opposition here, because their presence today is very important. Just 11 days ago, opposition leader Kem Sokha was arrested and is facing charges of treason. We are very much concerned that Cambodia has experienced no democratic change of government in 30 years, and that many opposition leaders have been imprisoned, now including two MPs.  Our second concern is the muzzling of the independent media: only 10 days ago, the Cambodian Daily was forced to close due to high tax bills, and in recent weeks a number of radio stations were closed. So we call on the government to provide, before next year’s parliamentary elections, a fair democratic space for opposition so that elections could really reflect the will of the majority of the Cambodian population.

name: Stanislav Polčák
text: for the PPE Group.- Mr President, I would also like to greet the representatives of the Cambodian opposition who are here with us today.The arrest of an opposition leader and his accusations of high treason and espionage is a truly extraordinary act.A court in Phnom Penh said it was an allegation of conspiracy with foreigners.Such a vague and unfounded accusation is, in my opinion, unprecedented.If the reasoning is given by the longtime prime minister of this state, Mr. Hun Sen, and he says that it is a secret conspiracy with the United States of America, then I think that at that moment such an attitude fulfills the attitudes against the rule of law.I think that is something we should unequivocally condemn.We are providing assistance to Cambodia, we should make it clear that we do not like this approach, that it is not possible to influence political electoral competition in this way.I clearly want to support the request for an observation mission.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I want to support the resolution that we will be voting on here today, because the situation in Cambodia is really deteriorating significantly. That is something you need to realize. The regime of Prime Minister Hun Sen has never been democratic, it has never been close to the rule of law, as we in Europe perceive it, and the situation is getting worse. The imprisonment of the opposition leader in the middle of this month, which is the news I am talking about, is really probably the culmination of what Hun Sen has shown so far. I just want to state that he himself threatened 9/11 by dissolving the main opposition party, which means that there is still a risk that the main opposition party may be dissolved before the elections next year, which will completely distort this election. It is really good for the European Union to take on the role of observer and clearly monitor more closely how next year's elections will take place in Cambodia, because I am very afraid that if the opposition parties are dissolved, the situation with the classic democratic elections will be far from approach.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to greet and absolutely urge the Cambodian opposition leaders present today to continue their battle, not to give up in the face of the undemocratic choices made by the Hun Sen regime. It is a country to which I am very attached, having also lived in the Cambodian house at the cité universitaire in Paris. The accusation of treason against the opposition leader Kem Sokha is yet another arrest of opposition members in the country while, in the meantime, the gag against the independent media continues to be increasingly tight. We also denounce the phenomena of land grabbing at the moment encouraged by the government and reiterate our call for a complete change in the climate towards the opposition and towards civil society to allow future political elections to take place in a democratic way. Finally, we invite the High Representative and the EEAS to consider, if the conditions are right, to send an observation mission so that it can be an encouragement to the Cambodian opposition, not only to introduce themselves, but to believe that a future for your country is actually possible.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, earlier this month, Cambodian opposition leader Kem Sokha was arbitrarily detained and in clear disregard for his parliamentary immunity. Two days later he was formally charged with treason by a Phnom Penh court and faces a sentence of 15 to 30 years in prison. This arrest is the culmination of weeks of political tension that led to the expulsion from Cambodia of the American NGO National Democratic Institute and the closure of 19 radio broadcasts and one of the few independent voices in the written press, the Cambodia Daily. What Kem Sokha's condemnation represents is yet another unacceptable attempt to neutralize the leadership of the main opposition political force, the National Rescue Party, whose good electoral results in the June municipal elections now make the Hun Sen regime afraid. that the parliamentary elections in July next year represent the end of the power that he has held since 1985 in that Southeast Asian country. Dear colleagues, this house cannot fail to condemn the detention of Kem Sokha and to appeal to the Cambodian authorities for his immediate release, as well as for respect for fundamental freedoms and the most elementary rules of the democratic game.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would also like to join the voices condemning the arrest and imprisonment of opposition leader Kema Sokha and the attacks on his party, the general tightening of the screws on the media and non-profit organizations.The Cambodian National Rescue Party, which is the subject of the attacks, is pursuing a policy of moving away from China and leaning towards the Western liberal model.That is why it is also uncomfortable for China and the Prime Minister.Prime Minister Hun Sen, who has ruled the country for over thirty years, is leading his country back to dictatorship.Cambodia is a country with great potential, but also a very turbulent history, especially during the tyranny of the Khmer Rouge.I want the people of this country to live freely and to be able to develop fully.Our resolution should support the democratic opposition and I greet its leaders here.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Colleagues have already presented the difficult situation of Cambodia, the problems of the opposition and their leader Kem Sokha. I believe that the acts of arrest and violence are also caused by the increased support for opposition groups during the last local elections in June. New amendments to the law on political parties and associations show forms of violation of fundamental human rights. I would also like to mention, as my colleague has already mentioned, one more element, very important for the rural population, from the perspective of growing sugar cane on large plantations by large companies with the consent of the government - this is ordinary land grabbing and taking over land traditionally used by these residents without adequate compensation, resulting in the loss of the main livelihood of this poorest part of society. Therefore, the Cambodian government must respect human rights, including the constitutional principles of pluralism, freedom of expression and association, which are a fundamental condition of the Cambodia-European Union cooperation agreement.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, last week, indeed, was a very sad week for Cambodia’s fragile democracy, a sad week for the freedom of the press – as many of you have said – and a sad week for the people of Cambodia. The arrest of the opposition leader, Kem Sokha, on 3 September and the closure of the Cambodia Daily the day after add to a long list of very serious developments in the country. These include continued restrictions on the freedom of expression, the closure of radio stations, arrests of members of the main opposition party and civil society actors. It is clear that this is a dangerous political escalation. These events suggest a further effort to restrict the space for democratic debate, independent media and civil society ahead of next year’s general elections. The continued use of judicial processes against opposition politicians and NGO figures is widely seen as politically motivated. On our side, as you have recognised, the European Union has called on the authorities to release Kem Sokha immediately. Earlier this year we made our voice heard very clearly when Cambodia amended the law on political parties twice to introduce provisions that would potentially allow for arbitrary dissolution of political parties. Such actions against opposition parties would cast a shadow on the July 2018 elections and ultimately call into question the very legitimacy of the vote. With regard to the elections, the European Union has provided support worth EUR 10 million to electoral reform, primarily through an improved voter registration process. We have worked closely with the Cambodian National Election Committee in support of electoral reform, mainly through an improved voter registration process. Our support has also included technical support on legal and civic education aspects and support to domestic election observation and monitoring of election-related violence. We will monitor closely the updates of the voters’ list that began on 1 September. We also deployed an EU election expert mission to Cambodia to follow the local elections last June. The EU delegation, to which some of you have referred, in close coordination with EU embassies and like-minded members of the international community, sent diplomatic observers to polling stations on election day. We have continuously urged the Cambodian authorities to take all necessary steps to ensure the conditions for credible, transparent and inclusive elections whose results will command the confidence of Cambodia’s voters. The EU has also expressed deep concern over the adoption by the Cambodian Parliament of amendments, as I said, to the law on political parties, and I have heard your considerations on the possibility of sending a fully-fledged EU election observation mission to the next political elections. If the political situation is conducive to a credible election process and if invited by the government, the European Union would be ready to consider the deployment of an EU election observation mission for the national elections due to be held in July next year. I believe that political developments in the coming weeks and months will be a key factor in assessing our possible deployment. The European Union and its Member States, on another issue that is also important: I have been proud to support the reconstruction and the development of the country from the very beginning. We have an important envelope of development cooperation with Cambodia that is embedded in a multi-annual cooperation programme for the period 2014-2020. All our programmes are implemented subject to close monitoring and on the basis of political and policy dialogue with the government. The respect of human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law are fundamental elements in our development policy and are closely monitored in this context. Our development cooperation with Cambodia is long term, and I have to tell you very clearly that any consideration regarding the possible suspension of cooperation would have to be carefully evaluated in terms of its impact, especially on the poor and vulnerable population, on people’s livelihoods and on better access for children to schools. These are the first priority in helping the Cambodian people. A large part of Cambodia’s population is still very vulnerable, and we will continue to closely monitor the situation and to use our development cooperation to improve the situation of the population. Cambodia has also been granted access to the European markets under the Everything But Arms scheme, which has served as an important driver of the country’s economic growth. You might be surprised that, despite our geographical distance, the European Union is today Cambodia’s biggest export market. But we also believe, as I said, that there can be no sustainable development with no human rights and no democratic guarantees, so we are using, and will continue to use, all the available channels to ask, and work, for a substantial change in the current political trends. The European Union is ready to continue to work with Cambodia towards a consolidation of its democracy and an equitable economic growth, but we look to the authorities of the country to take all the necessary steps to ensure that all political parties, civil society and the media can carry out their activities without fear, as should be the case in any functioning democracy.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today after the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - At a time when Cambodia, Laos and other issues are being discussed, Salah Hamouri, a 32-year-old Palestinian activist, was arrested on 23 August by the Israeli Union at his Jerusalem residence and sentenced by a military court to an administrative prison sentence. 6 months, which can be renewed indefinitely without any reason. This situation today affects hundreds of thousands of Palestinians. Salah Hamouri has already spent 7 years in Israeli prisons for a "crime of intent" related to an unproven attempt to murder a far-right religious leader and to belong to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. This administrative condemnation is based on a secret dossier inaccessible to defense lawyers and stems from a direct decision by Israel's defense minister, Avigdor Liberman, known for his racist, anti-Arab and anti-Palestinian statements. It should be noted that the wife of Salah Hamouri, together with their son, was and is prevented from entering Jerusalem. Only the passivity of the EU and the United States allows Israel to continue its policy of sabotaging the peace process, massacring the Palestinian population and undermining the creation of an independent state in accordance with UN resolutions.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the seven motions for resolutions on Gabon: the repression of the opposition (2017/2830 (RSP)).

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are again talking about Gabon here. We have already dealt with this last year, when our participation in the election observation mission, of which I was also a part, failed to guarantee fair and transparent elections but nevertheless highlighted the anomalies of the final election results . The problems then present were not only not solved but even degenerated, unfortunately, into violence and clashes. It is clear that the current political and social division in Gabon requires greater coordination and a doubling of efforts by all the Member States of the European Union, to guarantee not only political dialogue, peace and stability in the country, but also a real application of the Cotonou agreements, which unfortunately very often remain only written agreements or only words. Finally, I believe it is right to underline that the French military presence in Gabon, given the current process, the current European situation, should be coordinated by the European delegation. It would be important to demonstrate, on the part of the European Union, the will to abandon the mere anachronistic French colonizing presence and support the Gabonese people with the sole purpose of helping them find their way to the future.

name: Jo Leinen
text: author. – Mr President, I would like to say to Mrs Mogherini that Gabon must be a test case for the credibility of the Cotonou Agreement and our willingness to act. It can be a test case for restoring democracy in Central Africa. Ali Bongo is not a legitimate President. We know that he manipulated the last results and that he lost the elections. His reaction was brutal attacks on the opposition, with killings, imprisonment and repression all over the country. The people in Gabon are crying out for help, and they look to the United Nations – but also, and especially, to us. They are also looking to France, and I cannot understand why the EPP is making a split vote on our appeal to France to be more constructive and more active, because of their historic role and involvement in Gabon. I know that the intensive dialogue is going on. It should be finished, and then, if there are no results, we should take further steps. I think our credibility depends on us helping the people – especially young people – in this country.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author. - Mr. President, the presidential elections were indeed held in August 2016, about a year ago. There is no doubt that these were marked by heavy fraud, denounced by several observers, including the Union mission. And the announcement of the results was followed by violence that left too many dead. Since our resolution last February, the situation has hardly changed. It is therefore a sad anniversary that we commemorate here. Violence, arrests of opposition activists and even now travel bans of its leaders, including Mr. Ping. The silence, even the implicit support of the international community and in particular of France seems to give wings to Ali Bongo. This is why while supporting the resolution, we refuse its paragraph 9. The Gabonese unfortunately know very well that they cannot count on France and that, far from playing a constructive role, the successive governments of my country unfortunately protect, in fact, the financial interests of the ruling clan.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: author. –Mr President, Madam High Representative, 2009 and 2016, two rigged elections, two elections stolen by Ali Bongo and still the dead, hundreds of victims, the opposition repressed, persecuted, civil society and the media repressed. This violence, this flouted democracy is a political corruption which undermines, which plagues living together and plagues the cohesion of society. It is obviously no coincidence that this political corruption leans on, feeds on economic corruption. Too many Gabonese, European and French political and economic leaders are, in turn in this affair, corrupt and corrupters. If the words have a meaning in this forum, in the treaties, in the Cotonou Agreement, the European Union must do everything to ensure that democracy takes hold and it must implement sanctions for the perpetrators of abuses and abuses. crimes. We owe it for the credibility of this Parliament, we owe it to the Gabonese and, above all, we owe it to the Gabonese youth who have such an appetite for life, such an appetite for freedom, and who cannot be built. in resentment towards us and towards herself.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: Author. - Mr President, the presidential election held in Gabon in August 2016, instead of making things easier, has complicated the situation and violence has intensified in this area. At the same time, there was and still is a postponement of the parliamentary elections, which are supposed to take place at some point and is probably scheduled for April 2018. So the situation is deteriorating, human rights are limited. There are arrests of dissidents and activists. Of course, the issue takes on another dimension as, apparently, illegal profits that exist in Gabon are invested in France. French authorities have located and confiscated goods worth about 60 million euros. At the same time, there is a check in a bank account of 1.3 million euros which is located in France and belongs to the Bongo family. You realize that the issues are very serious. The European Union must intervene. The Gabonese regime must be pressured to abide by the Cotonou agreements.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: Author. - Tensions are mounting very much after last year's elections and there is indeed a question of the fairness and outcome of those elections. The opposition is silenced, there is a travel ban, there is talk of oppression, murders, arrests. The country is really in a political conflict. Social and political tensions are mounting very quickly. We must send a clear signal from the Union. We want to see Cotonou respected. We want peace to return. So we must appeal to the government to allow peaceful opposition. But that also means that we will ask the opposition to conduct peaceful opposition and also to end their acts of violence. Any country within the European Union that has a good relationship with Gabon and that can exert its influence should do so too. Only by being strong together as a Union, as President Juncker said yesterday, can we make a difference in foreign policy.

name: Joachim Zeller
text: Author. - Mr President, High Representative! A year ago, the people of Gabon were cheated of the outcome of an election. While the opposition candidate Jean Ping was apparently able to win over the majority of the voters in Gabon, the incumbent President Ali Bongo claimed the election victory and did everything to prevent the election from being re-examined. Popular protests were suppressed; many people were killed or injured in clashes with the security authorities. Many opposition politicians were imprisoned. Since then civil and human rights have been disregarded in Gabon. Gabon is a rich country, yet more than 80% of the people live in abject poverty because the income from oil and raw material exports ends up in the pockets of the president and his family. We must not abandon the citizens of Gabon who are deprived of their rights, and the considerable influence of the EU and its Member States - especially France - should be used to demand and promote a democratic dialogue in Gabon. And, Mr Leinen, that separate votes are requested for individual articles does not yet say anything about the voting behavior of a parliamentary group.

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: for the PPE Group.- Mr President, although the resolutions on Gabon have not yet been very successful in terms of outcome, we should not give up and should continue to respond to the use of violence and abuse of justice against political opponents, electoral fraud, restrictions on freedom of expression or restrictions and persecution of the opposition in general.The European Union must aim to help the people of Gabon develop democracy and civil society with credible and generally accepted independent institutions.The rule of law is not a superstructure, but a precondition for the prosperity we wish the citizens of Gabon.This position must be rigorously applied by the European Union, and in particular by those Member States that have an influence in Gabon, in all fora and more clearly in bilateral negotiations.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Colleagues! The political situation in Gabon, and in particular the doubts about the correctness of the last presidential elections or the unconstitutional postponement of the parliamentary election date, must cause concern for the international community. Even more disturbing are reports of violations of human rights and freedom of speech, and repressive measures against the opposition, including torture and killings. The European Union cannot condone the lack of transparency in the electoral process, so I believe that it is imperative that those guilty of using violence and electoral fraud be held accountable. I would like to remind you that the Gabonese Government, as one of the signatories to the Cotonou Agreement, committed itself to the principles of democracy, the rule of law and human rights, and therefore I believe that it is necessary to use both political and economic tools against Gabon to enforce these obligations and to ensure to stop using violence and repression against the opposition.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, Madam High Representative, naturally, I support the part of the resolution which reminds the Gabonese State of its obligations and responsibilities.I would like to express, like many here, my disapproval of the tricks that marred the polls.It is necessary, Madam High Representative, for Europe, everywhere in the world, to affirm its determination to promote both democracy and human rights.African peoples are particularly affected, tired and disillusioned with so much electoral masquerade, while subjects vital to them should be at the heart of policies: food issues, energy issues, land use planning and ecological threats.Ali Bongo, no more than others, cannot escape the verdict of the inhabitants in order to remain in power at all costs and direct the country's wealth to his exclusive profit.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, Gabon has not found peace since August 2016. The political climate is marked by violence, repression and the systematic violation of the rights and fundamental freedoms of its citizens, political opponents andhis diaspora.This Parliament calls for targeted sanctions against those responsible for electoral fraud and the violence which resulted from it.We recall that a delegation from the International Criminal Court has already visited Libreville.We await and strongly support the opening of an independent international investigation to bring justice to the victims of the regime in power.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, one year after the heavily contested presidential elections in Gabon, the situation has reached a stalemate, with no prospect of a political solution to the country’s divisions and to the crisis. It is quite clear to us that the new restrictive and repressive measures imposed on the opposition escalate the political and social tensions. In a moment when tempers are running high, also because of the downward economic trend, this is a very dangerous path to follow. We expect all parties to refrain from any statement or action that may fuel further tension. Gabonese law guarantees freedom of expression, assembly, movement and access to media for all the citizens of the country. This means that no one should be subject to arbitrary and legally unjustified arrests and restrictions. As you all know, at the beginning of the year we decided to call for an intensified political dialogue between the European Union and the Government of Gabon, in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. Months after our proposal, the government has accepted and the first procedural session of the dialogue was held this summer, in July. In September and October, we will hold four specific sessions of the dialogue, including one on the electoral process. Our conversation will be based on the final report of the EU’s Election Observation Mission, and I would like here to take again the opportunity to thank all the Members of this Parliament, and your former colleague and my new fellow Commissioner, Mariya Gabriel, for having led that mission in a remarkable manner. The conclusions of the Electoral Observation Mission were very clear. We cannot simply turn the page or allow others to turn the page. So the European Union’s relations with Gabon have been reassessed. Our aim is to prevent a lasting split in the country and to contribute to reconciliation. This requires that the government engages towards meaningful electoral and institutional reforms. We are ready to accompany the institutions in this process in any possible way. It is also essential to shed light on the serious human rights violations in the country. The preliminary examination of the International Criminal Court, the European Union’s intervention at the Human Rights Council in March, the resolution of the European Parliament and the resolution of the African Commission on Human and Peoples’ Rights all agree on this point. Truth must be established and those responsible for any violations must be brought to justice. The session of the UN Committee on Enforced Disappearances on Gabon was an opportunity for the government to take more seriously the numerous and well documented allegations of human rights abuses. Reconciliation will also need true dialogue between the parties. Unfortunately, the national dialogue process did not succeed in bringing together the main political forces. It is essential for us to find a new framework for a truly inclusive dialogue, with the ultimate goal of agreeing on structural reforms. We stand ready, as the European Union, to work with the government and the opposition, to help them find a way out of the crisis and towards transparent and credible future elections. For this aim, as I said, the remarkable work done by our Electoral Observation Mission will be incredibly valuable, an excellent basis for our further work. I thank you for that and also for this debate that I believe will provide us with good guidance for the further work that we will carry on.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today after the debate.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Laos, in particular the cases of Somphone Phimmasone, Lod Thammavong and Soukane Chaithad (2017/2831 (RSP)).

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: author. – Mr President, we are very concerned that, in Laos, arrests and forced disappearances of activists and protesters continue. In particular, those who have been critical of issues ranging from land disputes and corruption to the abuse of power are facing repression. This is underlined by the recent arrests and lengthy prison sentences for Somphone Phimmasone, Soukane Chaithad and Lod Thammavong. In compliance with the opinion of August 2017 of the UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention, we call for their immediate and unconditional release. In the resolution we also address the case of the leading civil society activist Sombath Somphone, who disappeared in December 2012. He was allegedly abducted by the police, and we have still not seen any reaction from the Laos Government. We call for transparent and impartial investigations into all pending cases of enforced disappearances.

name: Marc Tarabella
text: author. - Mr. President, Madam High Representative, last April, three young Laotians - whose names Ms. Lochbihler has just recalled - were sentenced to staggeringly long sentences for posting negative comments on social media. against power. 20, 16 and 12, these are the numbers we will use today. So many years in prison for only expressing their opinion about the government of their country. During their closed-door trial, the three young people were even forced to admit to having attacked the national security of their country, according to the Amnesty International report. Once again, Laos shows disrespect for basic human rights. How can we accept that a country applies such sentences just for words that do not please the government? It is high time that Laos granted UN special agencies, as well as representatives of humanitarian organizations, full access to its territory by allowing them contact with political prisoners and religious minorities. Laos must become more democratic, it may take time but it is essential that this happens, in parallel with the economic development of this country.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: Author. - Mr President, in Laos, three people are in prison for criticizing their Government on social media for issues such as corruption and deforestation problems in the country, and they face sentences of up to twenty years in prison. But this is not the only case that concerns us. The situation of enforced disappearances in the country is alarming, among them those of the environmental activists Somphone and Khantisouk, who fight against the multinational agricultural mega-projects in the country. From here we want to demand the paralysis of the mega-project of the Don Sahong dam, which will endanger the lives of millions of people in the region, violate their basic rights and have a serious impact on the Mekong River ecosystem. This is one more of the innumerable conflicts in the region stimulated by the predation of the multinationals on the resources and the territory. Last year the sad record for murders of environmental activists was broken, with a total of two hundred. Especially significant was the case of Berta Cáceres. This Parliament must have among its priorities the protection of these people, who defend our rights and those of the planet.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. - Without democracy there are no human rights and without human rights there is no democracy. That is very clear today in Laos. The freedom of speech, the freedom of association, the freedom of assembly: they are non-existent. This is useful for the Laotian People's Revolutionary Party, which is holding the country in a stranglehold. Other parties are not allowed. The Lao People's Democratic Republic cannot tolerate criticism, makes opponents disappear, oppresses religious minorities and uses the weapon of media and internet censorship. And especially, we draw attention to the fate of three brave people: Mrs. Thammavong and Messrs Phimmasone and Chaithad. They have been sentenced to long prison sentences and heavy fines because they raise and want to tackle the problems in the country and because they dream of a better future for the next generations. Critical voices have no place in prison. We therefore call on the Laotian government to release them immediately and unconditionally and to comply with the obligations arising from international human rights treaties.

name: Frédérique Ries
text: author. - Mr President, 48 years in prison between them. Almost half a century. It is the astounding sentence handed down last March against these three young Laotians guilty of posting negative comments on Facebook against the regime, one of the most repressive in this region. In fact, negative comments that are very harmless to us as Western Democrats. They denounced the human rights situation in the country, as well as deforestation and abusive corruption. Trial behind closed doors, therefore non-existent defense, ruthless verdict. It is this human rights situation in Laos, a country that we never talk about in this Chamber, that we never talk about outright, that we denounce here. In fact, it is a very quiet dictatorship that this unfair trial has just put in the spotlight. Madam High Representative, our question is simple and very complicated at the same time: what are we doing? What are in reality our leverage and do we have the will to activate them?

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: Author. - Commissioner, it will be very difficult for me to follow up on what has already been said here, because everything has been said here. We, as Members of all political groups, have come together to criticize the Laos regime, which consistently and relatively persistently violates all the human rights we can recall. In fact, I would like to begin by saying that, according to the latest Economist rankings, Laos is at the very bottom of the democracy index. It is generally known that there are frequent arrests for a different opinion, for publishing a post on social networks, this is also the case for these three people. But we could take the examples of dozens of other people who are being persecuted only for freedom of speech. Commissioner, I believe that it is this pressure and the union of all of us that will help get these people out of prison, as has happened in many cases. That is why I would like you to interpret this position of the European Parliament on the Laotian Government as well.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, why are the three activists mentioned in the resolution being persecuted? Because they made comments on the internet and in fact, when they made these comments, he was in Thailand and is being persecuted today by the Laotian authorities. They were also arrested by the Vietnamese police. So you understand the situation that prevails. An unacceptable situation as there is systematic repression of religious minorities in Laos, especially Christians who were beaten for participating in the celebration of Christmas. All these unacceptable situations in Laos must therefore be condemned. There must be intervention by the European Union, especially on the occasion of the Eurasian Summit. We cannot tolerate the restriction of human rights, the arrests of activists, the restrictions on the media and, above all, the oppression of Christians in Laos.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the European Union has been following very closely the arrest last year and the sentencing of the three citizens about whom we are debating today: Somphone Phimmasone, Lod Thammavong and Soukane Chaithad, three young people charged with criticising their government online while working abroad.  The European Union delegation has held several discussions on this case with the Lao authorities, including at ministerial level. We also raised the case in the EU-Laos Human Rights Dialogue that took place earlier this year. We asked for a fair and transparent trial that could be observed by the international diplomatic community, as well as access to lawyers and families for the detainees. Their three names were included in our list of persons of concern, based on the work we do with, and for, human rights defenders. During the dialogue we handed over this list to the authorities of Laos.  The sentences given to the three are long and disproportionate, as many of you have mentioned. After their arrest was announced, the authorities provided assurances that the international community would be able to observe the trial but we only learned about the hearing two months after it actually happened. The news was broken by the media, instead of being reported by the authorities, as should normally happen. The European Union is also following closely other similar cases in the country.  In our contacts with the authorities we have called on Laos to uphold its national and international human rights obligations. We have urged Laos to protect freedom of expression and association, and peaceful assembly. The right to a fair and transparent trial, and the right of detainees to obtain access to their families and to a lawyer should also always be assured. During the Universal Periodic Review in January 2015, under the auspices of the UN Human Rights Council, Laos committed to protecting freedom of expression, freedom of the press, freedom of assembly and association. All these rights are guaranteed by the National Constitution of Laos, as revised in 2015, and by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Laos ratified in 2009. We therefore expect Laos to maintain its own commitments taken at international and national level.  In a few months’ time, we will have another opportunity to formally raise this issue in our Human Rights Dialogue with Laos and we truly hope and believe that the situation should have been addressed by then. If that should not be the case, we will continue to raise the issue and will continue to discuss the situation with the authorities of the country.  These three young people have already spent over one year in jail, merely for having expressed their opinions in public, something which is completely normal in our democracies, as some of you have said. Every day they spend in custody is one too many.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today after the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The prison sentences handed down against Somphone Phimmasone, Soukane Chaithad and Lod Thammavon are just the latest in a long series.Arrests and disappearances, perpetrated against activists and demonstrators who have expressed legitimate views on territorial disputes, corruption and abuse of power, are sadly a sad reality in Laos.The government of Laos must respect the right to free expression and association and the rights of minorities, it must also respect the international commitments and obligations it has undertaken.We must strongly condemn the persecution of religious minorities and urge Laos to allow access to specialized UN agencies and representatives of humanitarian organizations.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Myanmar, in particular the situation of the Rohingya community (2017/2838 (RSP)).

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Author.- Mister President!The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights describes the excesses of violence in Myanmar as “like something out of a textbook for ethnic cleansing”.This violence must stop immediately and sufficient humanitarian aid must reach the people.Yes, there have been attacks on police stations that cannot be tolerated.But the military's response is extreme and cannot be justified by anything.The Myanmar government is now making the big mistake of not distancing itself from the disproportionate violence of the military.We demand an independent international commission of inquiry that can travel to the conflict area.This conflict absolutely needs a sustainable solution.The government must give the Rohingya citizenship or a legal status that gives them protection and rights.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the dramatic situation of the Rohingya describes very well the undemocratic drift present in Myanmar today and the attack on the Rohingya people has a double objective: that of an ethnic nature, that is to eliminate a minority, and that of a religious nature. that is, the will to suppress religious freedom - we are talking about a Muslim population. This is why the behavior of the Burmese authorities is serious: we condemn it and express our solidarity with the Rohingya people. We also ask Bangladesh, which we understand is in a difficult situation, to keep faith with its international obligations by not closing its borders and helping reception. Finally, a final reference to San Suu Kyi, today at the top of the Burmese government. We have been fighting her freedom battles for a long time but today she turns her head the other way and actually favors these attacks. I think that if this behavior continues, the European Parliament should decide on the procedure for withdrawing the Sakharov Prize awarded to you.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: author.- Mr President, an entire population made stateless in its own country is slowly and silently being decimated.Silence kills and we have a responsibility to act by naming atrocities, denouncing them, condemning them.Yes, let us condemn the atrocities, discriminations and crimes committed against the Muslim minority of the Rohingya, which are encouraged by the Burmese ultranationalist movements and which are perpetrated by the military.Let us denounce the guilty passivity of the government and in particular of the Nobel Peace Prize laureate, Aung San Suu Kiy, also winner of the Sakharov Prize and who has today become unworthy of this prize that we have awarded her.So let's adopt the joint resolution in which we call for an end to these massacres.

name: Amjad Bashir
text: author. – Mr President, as Edmund Burke said, all tyranny needs to get a foothold is for people of good conscience to remain silent. On Myanmar, some of us had wished for a still stronger resolution. Others felt that we should wait another month. The same procrastination allowed the genocide in Rwanda and Srebrenica. They also said that we should not jeopardise our on-going trade talks with Myanmar. How can we have trade, when the UN calls this a textbook example of ethnic cleansing? Trade cannot and should never thrive alongside tyranny. Cruelty is no culture for commerce. This resolution – not the first on Myanmar – represents a unified and determined response from Parliament. However, my fear is that, unless we all seriously consider sanctions and suspension of trade talks, there will no longer be any Rohingyas left.

name: Urmas Paet
text: author. – Mr President, the latest figure on Rohingyas fleeing ethnic cleansing in Myanmar are staggering. Out of around a million Rohingyas, already nearly 400 000 have crossed the border to Bangladesh, despite the hazardous circumstances on their way and the horrendous living conditions they meet upon arrival. At this rate, all of the Rohingyas will either be in Bangladesh or dead by the end of October. We must do what we can, and that is to say clearly that, if these atrocities do not stop, the European Union will consider punitive sanctions and also consequences in the context of trade preferences that Myanmar enjoys. Losing valuable investments is the only thing that will make the Myanmar army generals maybe understand that this cannot go on. In addition, humanitarian and medical aid must be provided to the camps in Bangladesh immediately. We cannot waste a day anymore. We have been watching these atrocities going on too long.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: author. - Mr. President, we are indeed sad to see that Aung San Suu Kyi is unable to handle this extremely worrying situation. The emergency now is access to humanitarian aid. I believe that this point needs to be emphasized. This is the priority. Then I want to tell you that the PPE Group has decided not to send any members next week to the INTA delegation. It is inconceivable to organize an INTA delegation at this time. On the other hand, the proposal of the PPE group - which I presented to the enlarged Bureau a few minutes ago - aims to organize within a few weeks an AFET and DROI mission, well prepared on both sides, in Myanmar and Bangladesh. . A mission not in the capitals, but on the ground, because you don't have to go there to listen to official speeches in the capitals. We have to get there when we can organize this.

name: Csaba Sógor
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the persecution of the Rohingyas, the largest stateless group in the world, is not a new phenomenon. They have been targeted for decades, during which thousands have lost their lives. What is different today is the brutality of the military campaign, which in no universe can be considered proportionate to the insurgent attacks carried out last month. What is unfolding before the eyes of the world is an inhuman process of ethnic cleansing. Solid reports confirm soldiers and militiamen raping and mutilating women, decapitating children and setting fire to buildings with people herded into them. What is also different is that all this is happening under the process the West sees as democratisation and under the government of a Nobel Prize winner, who would not even spell out the name of the people being massacred. The response of the EU should be firm in the face of this atrocity.

name: Soraya Post
text: for the S&D group.- Mr President!The terror in Burma does not fit into the Western world's narratives of military Muslims and peaceful Buddhists.Aung San Suu Kyi's tacit consent does not fit into our image of the hero who stood up to militarism.Aung San Suu Kyi, you have been a role model for me too, but now it is impossible to remain silent.On satellite images, we see how villages, where children have just played, mothers fetched water and fathers plowed fields, are now burnt down and emptied.So many have died on the run through the jungle.Many drowned refugees have been fished up in Bangladesh.Aung San Suu Kyi, your silence must also end.Your struggle has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize and the Sakharov Prize.If you fail, you will not only lose the prizes, you will lose your honor.We, the EU, must react and act now.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, in Myanmar / Burma, not only is there a huge religious and ethnic persecution against the Rohingya community, but we are also witnessing massive evictions of thousands of small farmers to take over their land. The land law and the new foreign investment law in Myanmar / Burma are allowing the massive inflow of transnational capital, promoting mining extractivism, the sale of timber, industrial agriculture for export and the grabbing of water. The expulsion of the Rohingya from their territory not only responds to a religious or ethnic conflict, but is also generating big business. Without going any further, the Government of Myanmar / Burma recently allocated more than one million hectares of this community to agro-industrial projects. The European Union cannot be jointly responsible for this tragedy. We demand from here that an effective stand be taken against the harassment and expulsion of these communities, for the defense of the land of the Rohingya community and of all the workers, including the landless and those displaced by the armed conflict.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Madam High Representative, the Muslim Rohingyas, described by the United Nations as a stateless and friendless people, from Myanmar, have been victims of torture, neglect and repression since the independence of that country in 1948. But now, after an illegitimate and totally disproportionate military response to attacks by an armed Rohingya group, the atrocities in the state of Rakhine have reached proportions never before reached and have caused more than 300,000 refugees to flee to Bangladesh, where many of them are fleeing. need urgent humanitarian aid. This brutal repression and the persistent serious violations of human rights unfortunately mean the death of the hope of consolidating democracy and national reconciliation that the November 2015 elections represented for many. This Parliament cannot fail to strongly condemn all attacks in Rakhine State and remind Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar's State Councilor and de facto leader of the country that, as a 1990 Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has special responsibilities in the promotion of religious and ethical tolerance and in the fight against all forms of radicalism, being unable to refer to the silence in the face of this true humanitarian catastrophe.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we all share the sense of horror at what is happening to the largely Muslim Rohingyas in Myanmar. I want to thank all those constituents and citizens who have contacted us to raise their concern. The international community cannot sit by while a Nobel Peace Prize laureate oversees what the UN has called ‘textbook ethnic cleansing’. These crimes must stop. We also know that words are not enough, and mass atrocities like this go on despite diplomatic statements and resolutions. The EU needs a robust, joined-up strategy for dealing with situations like this around the world, to apply real pressure to stop the violence and to work together with international partners and grassroots anti-racist organisations to bring perpetrators to justice.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the issue of the Rohingya ethnic minority has been discussed several times here in the European Parliament: in July 2016, in December 2016 and, of course, in the beginning, in March 2017. What is happening is an ethnic cleansing and This is done purely for economic reasons, in order to seize the land where the Rohingya communities lived, because there is interest in mining. Interest from large multinationals. At the same time, they seize the exploitation of water. Therefore, religion is used as an excuse. The fact that the Rohingya happen to be Muslims has nothing to do with it, because behind it all is an economic process. This is what we must see and this is what we must stand for, condemning the violence on the part of the military and, of course, calling for immediate measures to stop the ethnic cleansing that is currently taking place in Burma. We would expect Aung San Suu Kyi, who has also been awarded the Sakharov Prize, to have taken a very decisive position. We are therefore waiting for action by the European Union, Mrs Mogherini.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: –The reports are sickening.Thousands of Rohingyas are killed every day, chased from their homes, children are crushed.There is an ethnic cleansing, a genocide going on.This is going on in 2017!I regret that some colleagues even dare to dispute that.The Rohingyas are actually trapped like rats.International organizations do not get there and even when they want to flee, they cannot get away.This is being watched by someone who has won the Nobel Peace Prize, someone who has won the Sakharov Prize.We should ask ourselves what we expect from that person and whether we can take those titles.But it is of course more important that actions are taken, that people are protected.We cannot do this alone as Europe, but we can exert our influence in the world to exert pressure and work together to ensure that the persecution of the Rohingyas finally ends.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I also speak in my capacity as Chair of the Delegation for South Asia, which covers Bangladesh as one of our countries and where in the past we visited the Rohingya camps down at Cox’s Bazar. So we know this is something which has been going on for a very long time and where the European Union has been a key funder in terms of supporting the Rohingya people in Bangladesh – the refugees there. We gather that the EU has currently put in EU 3 million from ECHO funding in light of the current situation. We would ask how that is actually being spent, given that it is also, apparently, covering Myanmar. And we know, as we have just heard, that there is no access for the UN and INGOs in North Rakhine State, which is something we need to push to reinstate. We need a UNHCR—led body down in Bangladesh, but we also need a strong response from the European Union and all its governments and active diplomacy in the region, not least with the two big powers, because this is something that is ongoing. People need to be able to return home in dignity with their rights restored. This is something which is not just about Aung San Suu Kyi; it is about the generals and their military power too. Don’t let them off the hook.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the tragedy affecting the Rohingya people is a terrible tragedy. Although this House has already dealt with this unfortunate people in more than one circumstance, directly with the resolutions of 7 July of 14 December 2016, and indirectly with the resolutions of 15 March and 13 June this year, the situation unfortunately it has not changed, indeed it has gotten worse. According to UNHCR estimates, more than 300,000 Rohingya have sought refuge in Bangladesh in the past two weeks alone, escaping persecution, while satellite images show entire villages razed to the ground, in an area where no access to both NGOs and UN observers. We are talking about an entire people who have been deprived of citizenship since 1982, a people of stateless persons. Civilians arriving in Bangladesh often have bullets in their bodies, while the border between Myanmar and Bangladesh has even been mined, in order to prevent the return of these poor wretches to their homeland. We are talking about a huge tragedy, for which we strongly and urgently ask for concrete actions, for example we can think of withdrawing the Sakharov prize, we should cancel the INTA mission to be held next week: it seems absurd to me to go and talk about trade in front of situations like that.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, as has been said here, this is a repeated debate on the Rohingya case. I also spoke last time, and I must say that, of course, this continuing and escalating violence must be condemned. But we ourselves see that condemnation by the European Parliament alone is useless, but, on the contrary, the situation is escalating. We are talking about another three hundred thousand Rohingya who were expelled to Bangladesh, and the border was mined so that they could not return to their homeland. I think that there is a real need to talk about concrete sanctions, about what the European Commission can do, what the European Union institutions can do at the moment in terms of sanctions against the Burmese regime, and, above all, about what humanitarian aid to provide, because the situation in Bangladesh is very tense. Bangladesh is currently feeding several hundred thousand refugees on its territory. These are probably specific things we can do. So I also share the condemnation and disillusionment with the Nobel Prize winner, but the main culprit in the whole situation is the army in Burma, we should not forget that.

name: Wajid Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, these atrocities against the Rohingya community have to stop. I welcome the resolution today. Aung San Suu Kyi’s disgraceful reaction is prompted by the fear that speaking out in support of the Rohingyas will trigger an angry reaction from the military. And yet looking away while a genocide is taking place is shameful. Avoiding confrontation at the UN General Assembly is not the reaction of a Sakharov Prize laureate or any democratic leader.  We must push the Myanmar Government to allow international aid to those that need it. We also need to ratchet up pressure on China, which holds influence over the military in Myanmar. In the words of Archbishop Desmond Tutu: ‘A country that is not at peace with itself, that fails to acknowledge and protect the dignity and worth of all its people, is not a free country’.  We look to the High Representative Madam Federica Mogherini to end the suffering for the Rohingyas; please, Madam, for the Rohingyas and please, for humanity.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are facing yet another humanitarian drama. It is not the first time that the Muslim Rohingya minority in Myanmar has suffered violence: arbitrary deprivation of nationality, restriction of freedom of movement, threats to life and security, denial of the right to health and education, and restriction of political rights. United Nations Special Rapporteur for Human Rights Yanghee Lee already speaks of a thousand dead and 200,000 Rohingya Muslim refugees who have entered Bangladesh to escape violence in Burmese territory. The Burmese leader Aung San Suu Kyi, on whom Europe has always placed every hope for the pacification of the area, rejects with disdain the accusations of repression or even genocide against the Rohingya, labeling the news circulating in the West as fake news. Therefore, it is precisely to this lady that we turn to ensure that a peaceful solution can be reached as soon as possible, which takes into account respect for dignity and human rights.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, as we all know very well, Myanmar went through over half a century of military rule and isolation. Those of you that referred to the history, and even the present, of the country and the role of the military are perfectly right. We have to look at the events of these weeks and we also have to look at the history of the country. In the last few years the country has gone through impressive change and yet the path towards an inclusive and diverse democracy is far from accomplished. Let me start by stating clearly one thing – the European Union has condemned the attacks of 25 August by the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army, as well as the violence that followed in Northern Rakhine State. We believe that the perpetrators must be brought to justice in line with the rule of law. Let me also state, just as clearly as what I said just now, that we are very much aware of and concerned about the excesses during the security operations conducted by Myanmar security forces. This has led to a massive flow of refugees into Bangladesh, one of the most terrible refugee crises of our time. This situation is completely unacceptable and risks destabilising the wider region.  We have two immediate priorities and I was glad to see that the UN Security Council discussed this issue last night. UN Secretary-General António Guterres expressed similar priorities to the one I will share with you in a moment. First immediate priority: end the tensions, the violence; de—escalate. Violence must stop immediately. Human rights must be respected by all but it is very clear: security forces face a special responsibility to refrain from any violence against unarmed civilians. Secondly, and I think Mr Preda mentioned this, humanitarian aid should be brought to those in need urgently. Here we have a European Union role to play that we are playing in a quite a remarkable manner. I would like here to thank Commissioner Stylianides for the dedication of his work, which is also proving to be essential in this moment and in this case. There are 350 000 vulnerable people in Rakhine. They need to be urgently reached by humanitarian aid and aid workers. For many of them, this is a matter of life or death.  My colleague Stylianides and I are working very closely to address this issue and yesterday, upon our insistence, a lot of diplomatic work, the government communicated that the International Red Cross will be able to fly in and aid 30 000 of them.  But let me be clear, this is a welcome step that can only be the beginning of a path that we have to see continuing, because the Bangladeshi authorities have welcomed the many refugees who fled their homes and the international community – and we, first of all, I believe – should not only praise but also support their efforts. As an immediate response to the current situation, the European Union has decided to increase our support to Bangladesh with another EUR 3 million, on top of the EUR 12 million aid already provided for Myanmar and Bangladesh together. These are the two immediate priorities: end the violence and bring in humanitarian aid. But then we have another important task to carry out. We will continue to work with everyone involved to find lasting peace in Myanmar to the benefit of the whole population, addressing the structural issue of Rakhine. As you mentioned, this is not the first time we have come on this issue. This means that, beyond the acute moment of crisis, we have a responsibility to work on the political scene.  There is no doubt that one of the underlying causes of instability in the region is the status of the Rohingya minority in Myanmar and the underdevelopment of Rakhine State. Addressing the situation is what we have always asked for in our political dialogue with Myanmar over the years, including at high-level meetings and in the EU-Myanmar Human Rights Dialogue. As you know, the last resolution adopted by the Human Rights Council, last March, was also a European Union initiative. The recommendations of the final report of the Advisory Commission on Rakhine State headed by Kofi Annan are our point of reference. The Government of Myanmar has committed itself to taking this report forward and I discussed this issue personally with Aung San Suu Kyi during her visit to Brussels just a few months ago.  Recommendations include the issue of discrimination, poverty alleviation, assurance of basic rights, equal access to education and social services, as well as the promotion of trust and reconciliation. The time to implement the Annan Report is now because we are seeing what the people of Rakhine are facing and they cannot wait any longer. We are ready to support the implementation of these recommendations in all possible ways. The Government of Myanmar should also continue its cooperation with the United Nations and make it stronger including with the UN Special Rapporteur and the UN Human Rights Council’s independent fact-finding mission. This is also something we discussed with Aung San Suu Kyi and just last week, once again, all these points were raised directly with the Government of Myanmar by a European Union delegation headed by the European External Action Service (EEAS) and, as you can imagine, by our EU delegation on a daily basis.  Our coordination stays strong with the UN, personal contacts from my side with Secretary-General Guterres and with my colleagues all over the world on this issue, and we will use the UN General Assembly ministerial week for continuing intensive consultations and to guarantee that the international community can stay united in facing this issue. Myanmar’s struggle for democracy has been a source of inspiration for many around the world, and for me personally and I believe for many of you in this room. The responsibility that the country’s leadership, civilian but also military, faces today is immense exactly because they have been, San Suu Kyi in particular, a source of inspiration for the democratic world. They need to show that the democracy they fought so hard fought can work for all the people of Myanmar, beyond ethnic, social and religious boundaries. During Myanmar’s fights for democracy, the international community and Europe never left the people of Myanmar alone and we will not leave them alone now.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today after the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
