text: in writing.- The volatile domestic situation in Myanmar is of particular concern.The Rohingya minority faces repression and persistent serious human rights abuses, including threats to life and security.In addition, a statelessness law was passed against this national minority.The situation in the country is critical.It is therefore vital that the Myanmar Government take action as soon as possible to prevent ethnic persecution and eliminate statelessness.In addition, restrictions on the Rohingya's rights and freedoms must be prevented.There are massive human rights violations in Myanmar, people are killed, people are fleeing Myanmar, and the wounded are not receiving the necessary medical care.Humanitarian aid organizations must be given immediate access to the state of Myanmar.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - Rohingya Muslims have been one of the most vulnerable ethnic groups in the world for years. They are exposed to the most brutal forms of punishment, including murder, persecution, torture, rape, burning of homes and entire villages. The violence perpetrated against Rohingya Muslims can be characterized as a crime against humanity and it is necessary to ensure full accountability for the perpetrators and justice for the victims. Their right to move is increasingly limited from year to year, so that it has become almost impossible to get a job and work, to receive appropriate medical care. They were also denied the right to education. The only education is primary and sometimes secondary, which they eventually acquire in madrasas and mosques, which they are forbidden to build. They are people without any rights and without citizenship. It is time for this terror against Rohingya Muslims to come to an end. It is necessary to find ways to ensure a just and peaceful coexistence of different worldviews. Human rights belong to all people in every society and should be inalienable. Everyone has the right to their faith, it is something that cannot be alienated from anyone. We must not turn a deaf ear to the problems of Myanmar’s Muslims, we must work together to find a solution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - The United Nations reports that in less than two weeks, 370,000 Rohingyas fled abuses by the Burmese army to seek refuge in Bangladesh and more than 400 have been killed. The United Nations calls the repression carried out by the Burmese military "ethnic cleansing". We must act as soon as possible. I call on the Union to urgently engage in a dialogue with the Burmese authorities to end this inhuman situation, to protect civilians and to restore respect for human rights. The refusal of access to humanitarian aid by the Burmese authorities is a violation of international law. The Union must do its part in order for humanitarian organizations to come to the aid of the displaced people. As Vice-Chair of the Committee on International Trade, I am opposed to maintaining a delegation of parliamentarians in Burma to discuss trade and investment. I also questioned the Chairman of this committee on this subject. Finally, it is unbearable to watch, Aung San Suuu Kyi, former Nobel Prize winner and Sakharov Prize winner, deny the accusations of ethnic cleansing and fall silent in deafening silence. The possibility of withdrawing the Sakharov Prize from him must be seriously considered.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote : see Minutes)

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as all the votes seem to be close and as you seem to be checking every single one, why don’t we just do them all electronically directly? It would be quicker.

name: President. –
text: Thank you for the suggestion. This way everybody would be at peace. – After the vote:

name: Morten Løkkegaard
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, in accordance with Rule 59(4), I would like to send this report back to the committee in order to start interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Ulrike Rodust
text: Rapporteur.- Mister President!I just want to ask that this report be referred back to committee so that we can start the interinstitutional negotiations quickly.

name: Arnaud Danjean
text: protractor.- Mr. President, this is not about reopening a substantive debate, we are asking for authorization to enter into interinstitutional negotiations on a text which was the subject of a broad agreement in the Foreign Affairs Committee and whichis also based on a broad compromise.I would like to remind you that the text we are discussing comes from an initiative launched by the High Representative in December 2013, that a lot of time has been lost and that the result of the negotiations that we will start is awaited with great urgency byEuropean missions which are deployed in Mali, Somalia and the Central African Republic and which need the funding that we are going to offer them.

name: President. –
text: Who would like to speak against? Mrs Hautala, you have the floor.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the legal basis for this proposal is incorrect. We should not turn a blind eye when a Common Foreign and Security Policy instrument is masked to look like development policy. The legal services of all institutions, also in this Parliament, were very reluctant to approve the proposed legal basis, and in the Committee on Legal Affairs in July, the legal basis of this proposal was pushed through by minority votes, while the majority of the committee was voting against or abstaining. There can hardly be development without security, but that should not mean that legal bases are interchangeable. Article 209 on Development Cooperation and Development Cooperation Instrument funds cannot be used to finance military capacity-building abroad. We have to make clear that, also internally, we respect the rule of law in the European Union institutions. Many of us may think that the European Union, and especially the European Parliament, should have more of a say in the Common Foreign and Security Policy matters, but it does not mean that we should sacrifice the development policy principles and bend legal rules. That should not be done. This regulation would create the precedent that development aid and non-Common Foreign and Security Policy instruments and funds are used for military purposes and development funds are used for capacity-building for the armed forces. These activities go far beyond development policy. Therefore, I ask you to vote against starting the negotiations. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Mrs Federica Mogherini, would like to say a few words. You have the floor.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I understand you are under time pressure, but I think we are discussing something important. Just to confirm what Mr Danjean said: this decision to enter negotiations has been long awaited. Next week in New York, many of our partners – the Central African Republic, the Horn of Africa, the Sahel – will ask us again, as they have done for many years now, if we are ready to do more to support their own work on peace and security, and I would really like finally to bring them good news after four years. This is not about moving the objective from development to security. On the contrary, it is to fulfil SDG No 16 that links development and security and asks all international players also to dedicate resources to guarantee that the security conditions are there for the development work to be effective. So I hope for a wise decision from this Chamber. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: Thank you very much. We will now decide by roll call vote.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, can you please explain to this House under what provision in our rules is it permitted for an outside institution to intervene in a debate in the course of votes taking place? (Applause)

name: President. –
text: I think that if we raise these sorts of questions – why the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative, who is with us all the time – we question her credentials to come and tell us something which is relevant to the vote which we are taking, I think we should not expect that. (Shouting and applause) I therefore open the vote.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Mr President, only 4.2% of people with disabilities have a job in Romania. In the European Union, the percentage reaches 50%. However, the percentage in the European Union is also low. A Europe for all must be not only a slogan, but also a reality. Therefore, people with disabilities must have full and very easy access to products and services, to everything that means cultural life, to everything that means transport, access to the internet, bank transfers and so on. There must be no difference between what we can do, those without disabilities and what those with disabilities can do. Therefore - and all this is reflected in the labor market - it must have a place in the labor market and vocational training, and school training, all this leads to finding a job. Therefore, I support special measures to increase the percentage of 50% in the European Union, of course, in Romania as well.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: - Mr President, whoever accuses the 5 Star Movement of always saying no is either deaf or in bad faith.When the rules and citizens are respected, the 5 Star Movement is always there, and we have demonstrated it with our "yes" to the treaty for the trade of organic products with Chile. Unlike CETA and TTIP, it is an honest agreement, which allows our quality products to enter a new growing market and our citizens to rely on safe and certified products.Italy is a leader in the organic sector with 1.3 million hectares of cultivated area, 55,000 operators and a turnover of over four billion euros.We want to make this sector grow even more and suggest expanding this type of agreement to other countries.This is the vision of trade according to the 5 Star Movement and we say a strong "yes" to this type of agreement.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Mr President, transparency, accountability and integrity in the European institutions mean a very simple principle: to respect the law and to make laws for the citizens. Not for interest groups, not for industries, not for lobbyists. We, here, represent the citizens. It is unacceptable that we do not yet have a mandatory transparency register and it is still optional and we have had a debate for years that shows us how much opposition there is to a mandatory lobby register. For every law that comes out of this institution, people need to know who they met, who their listeners and representatives listened to. It is a shame that we still do not have a European program for the protection of those whistleblowers (in Romanian: integrity warnings) and investigative journalists. Because they are the ones who discover the illegal things in the institutions, including the European institutions, and, as such, they must be protected. Therefore, I again call for the adoption as soon as possible of a mandatory register of transparency, protection of witnesses, whistleblowers and investigative journalists. And also the reform of the European institutions, because we have too many and too many employees. In order to move forward, we need to be a little smaller and more flexible and only focus on what is important.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: - Mr President, citizens' trust in the EU institutions is fundamental to democracy, good governance and effective policy-making. That is why the institutions of the European Union must strive to achieve the highest possible standards of transparency, accountability and integrity. These principles are key and complementary components in promoting and ensuring greater openness in the EU institutions and in its decision-making process. Transparency and accountability in public spending must be in line with the greatest possible degree of openness. The fact that openness is appropriate is also evidenced by the fact that in 2014 OLAF recommended the recovery of EUR 476.5 million from the Structural Funds and we found that the competent authorities had recovered only EUR 22.7 million. That is why I join the call for the Member States to give priority to the correct allocation of EU funds and to make every effort to recover them if they have not been allocated or used correctly.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this report because there is a clear need for more transparency, more visibility and more clarity on how decisions are made in the institutions. The loss of confidence in the Union, in its institutions, is precisely due to the impression of the citizens of the countries that are members of the European Union that these institutions make their decisions non-transparently and under pressure from lobby groups. And there is definitely lobbying. I can point to lobbying interests in the field of road transport, where a number of lobbying companies are pressuring their own countries to draft legislation that is to the detriment of countries or, rather, entrepreneurs in Eastern Europe, lobbying amendments that run counter to free movement, of free initiative. So the institutions need to be reformed, lobbyists need to be put on a list, and it needs to be clear who makes the decisions and who spends the taxpayers' money.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Mr President, more than 3,000 Romanian students go to study in the Erasmus program at European universities every year.The Erasmus + program is a very valuable tool that allows for the exchange of experience, which allows education in various countries of the Union and the exchange of good practices in the field of education.The current Erasmus + program has a budget of 14.7 million euros and is insufficient.The number of students, teachers and researchers who benefit from this program is growing every year, which means that it is a good and effective program.Therefore, the Erasmus budget needs to be increased and this needs to be done in the next multiannual financial framework 2020. Only in this way will we respond to the growing demand for Erasmus + mobility programs in the light of ideas highlighting the benefits of mobility for higher education, innovation, research and citizens' progress.the progress of the European Union.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Undoubtedly, the Erasmus + program is not perfect, but that does not mean that it should be denied. On the contrary, it needs to be financially strengthened and the qualification procedure also needs to be improved. On this occasion, I would like to speak up in particular to young people from the Eastern Partnership area. It is there that the purpose of this program is the most perfect, the best and the most effective, and therefore I believe that the mechanism of attracting students from this area must be definitely improved. I am very glad that several applications have been rejected that either spoiled or denied this program. Fortunately, these adjustments have been made - during discussions, debates and as a result of voting - which strengthen the program. I would also remind you that this debate and this resolution are the aftermath of the question about the future of Erasmus +. And the question arose in relation to the shortcomings of financial guarantees, as well as the procedure for selecting students themselves. I am very glad that we were able to adopt this resolution today.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I am a strong supporter of the Erasmus program, so I voted in favor of this resolution. As you can imagine, working on this program was a real challenge for colleagues. However, thanks to good cooperation and the efforts of everyone, we have managed to achieve a balanced and positive result that will have a more positive effect on education and training programs throughout the European Union. Our goal was to focus mainly on the success achieved by this program, as well as on the future challenges it poses. With the final test, we will be able to achieve just that for our educational and training programs, especially for the younger generations, who will soon feel these positive effects.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, probably few people question Erasmus + as one of the Union's most significant achievements, directly experienced by European citizens. We need this success story, all the more so as it can contribute to the worldview of future generations, to shaping their character and to their belief in a common Europe. There may not be much debate about continuing the program and increasing its resources, but I would also like to draw attention to the recommendations of the relevant EP report adopted at the beginning of the year. In particular, which unfortunately points to the social selectivity that can still be experienced in the program today: lower-income students have limited access to the program, and a high proportion of students participating in the program are financially supported by their families. There is a need for detailed rules that allow mobility for everyone, including those who have to take a job to fund their studies, as a lot of young people do.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: - Mr President, I supported the motion for a resolution because I also consider the Erasmus + program to be one of the most important and best programs that the European Union has. In the thirty years of its existence, this program has positively affected more than nine million EU citizens, which is almost twice the number of Slovakia's population. At a time when Eurosceptism is on the rise in the Member States, when young people do not have a vision of their future, we need to strengthen this program and make it even more effective. It is important that we talk about its success, that we bring it even closer to young people, teachers, because in my personal experience, there are still schools, school facilities, institutions that did not use this program because they did not have enough information. Every year, Erasmus gives young people the opportunity to contact peers from other Member States and, in addition to acquiring language skills, it is also a real bridge to Europe.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, of course I voted and supported the report, and I support its rapporteur, my colleague Nekov, who is in the Chamber. It is imperative not only to focus on traditional training programs, but also to support formal and non-formal programs, as well as lifelong learning programs. This report on the new skills program rightly highlights a number of areas that require better and better cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and their educational institutions. Two points I would like to emphasize are the importance of vocational education and training and the timely implementation of the Council's recommendations, increasingly necessary steps for further progress.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Mr President, thank you to all the colleagues who supported the report. I am naturally happy that the new European Skills Program has been adopted by a large majority. As rapporteur for the Committee on Culture and Education, I dare say that the European Commission's initial proposal, albeit on a large scale, has been significantly improved, especially as regards the missing social element. I believe that the goals of the Skills Program can only be achieved by applying a holistic approach to skills development, according to which the learner must be at the center of the process. In the same way, access to education, training and skills development must be equal for all, including the most vulnerable members of society. In conclusion, I would like to say that improving the skills of European citizens will depend to a large extent on improving the skills of our teachers. Therefore, it is necessary to allocate financial resources for their professional development, as well as to implement measures to increase the attractiveness of the teaching profession. We must not forget that they are the pillar of the education system.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, just as technological and trade patterns are shifting, industrial employment is declining and jobs become more sophisticated and demanding, skill shortages in European economies are becoming more and more apparent. Against this situation, the Commission’s new skills agenda initiative is extremely welcome even though the role of the EU in this field is only a supportive one. Just as the foundation of long-term productivity and growth is a highly skilled workforce, the key to developing such a workforce lies in education systems and investment in education staff. Ensuring quality education at all stages, including lifelong learning possibilities regardless of age, must be an absolute priority for us. This is why I, for one, would be extremely glad to see European Semester recommendations on minimum levels of investment in education and training, as well as minimum levels of education quality in Member States that lag behind.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: - Mr President, skills and knowledge are the only basis for our prosperity and social security. According to the latest OECD study, 70 million Europeans lack basic skills such as reading, writing and numeracy. This is an insurmountable obstacle for people looking for a decent job for an adequate standard of living. Therefore, the new Skills Agenda for Europe is a long-awaited initiative rightly focused on the need to modernize Europe's education and training systems in line with the rapidly changing economic and social environment. Therefore, access to education and training opportunities must be a right for everyone and at every stage of life. I agree with the Commission's proposal to urge the Member States to draw up comprehensive national strategies for basic skills, with the necessary preconditions for personal and professional fulfillment. In our strategies, we must not forget to support the professional development of teachers and educators as a fundamental core of the education system.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the major question under Rule 130b of the Rules of Procedure by Beatrix von Storch and Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, on behalf of the EFDD Group, to the Commission on the abolition of UNRWA (O-000061/2017 - 2017/2834 (RSP)) (B8-0325 / 2017).Unfortunately, the EFDD Group that tabled this Big Question has no one here today.That is why this major question is not being tabled and Commissioner Crețu speaks immediately.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of Parliament, you know very well that the Palestine refugees question has existed for almost 70 years. The United Nations General Assembly established and mandated the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East to provide assistance and protection to register Palestine refugees pending a just and lasting solution. Only in December 2016 the General Assembly extended the Agency’s mandate for three years by a large majority. The European Union’s continued support to the Agency is a key element in the European Union’s strategy of contributing to the promotion of stability in the Middle East and to the viability of the two-state solution, which is an essential political horizon for Arab-Israeli relations. The Agency’s work helps to ensure that the essential needs for the well-being, protection and human development of Palestine refugees are met. Over many years the agency has demonstrated its capacity to provide education, health, relief, and social services. A future independent Palestinian state needs education, skills and healthy citizens to deliver peace, security and prosperity for all. The Agency’s work provides political space for efforts that need to be considerably intensified to conclude a peace deal and to pursue Palestinian state-building. In each education service delivered, the Agency focuses on respect for human rights and for the fundamental freedoms. In doing so, it gives young Palestinians a perspective for their future, it represents a bulwark against violent radicalisation. The European Union is by far the most predictable donor to the Agency and will continue to be so, as reflected in the Joint Declaration on European Union support to the Agency on 7 June. Since 1971 the EU has been providing reliable and predictable support to the Palestine refugees through the Agency programmes, special projects and emergency appeals. The European Union and its Member States are by far the largest provider of assistance to Palestine refugees. Mr President, honourable Members, today’s debate was triggered by a so-called major interpellation introduced by one Parliamentary Group, as you said, alleging that this Agency mismanages EU funds and tolerates terrorist activities. Our view is quite the opposite. In 2014 the Agency successfully passed the EU’s seven-pillar assessment, which evaluated its internal control, accounting, external audit and procurement systems. Assurances have been provided as the Agency’s processes and mechanisms are in place to ensure the neutrality of these facilities, including monitoring of facilities by its staff members, regular informal inspection of the Agency’s installations by operation support officers, and a strict no-weapons policy in the Agency’s installations. The Agency explicitly condemns all acts of terrorism in the strongest possible terms and regularly does so whenever any such act is carried out. It also remains the Agency’s policy to always investigate credible allegations of neutrality violations. Where violations of staff rules and regulations are established, appropriate disciplinary action is taken. The agency has indeed taken forthright actions whenever allegations of incitement have surfaced. The major interpellation also suggests merging the Agency with the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The Commission is not in favour of such a merger. The reasons are obvious: the Agency has a specific mandate, with staff going beyond the usual humanitarian aid, and a broader relevance, not only in Palestine but also in Jordan, Lebanon and Syria. Mr President, honourable Members, the European Union is committed to the two-state solution as the only viable way to achieving lasting peace in the Middle East. The European Union is convinced that any solution to the Israeli-Arab conflict will need to encompass an agreed, just and fair solution to the refugee question, allowing the two future states to live side by side in peace and security. Whatever the difficulties – and they are real – the region should not lose sight of this goal.

name: Fernando Ruas
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mr President, in July I requested a debate on forest fires.At the time, only Portugal and Spain were affected countries.Today we add Croatia, France, Greece and Italy, which demonstrates the scope of this sad reality.In fact and in my country alone, 214,000 hectares of forest burned this year and until August 31.This figure represents more than 234% of the burnt area than the average of the last ten years for the same period and, in the context of European aid, it is therefore important to know whether the Commission envisages the flexible application of the Solidarity Fund as requested now.On the ground, populations need immediate help.

name: Der Präsident.
text: - Mr Ruas!You are currently commenting on the next Big Question.We're talking about the first major inquiry.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: - Mr President, but that is where I asked to speak.It was exactly for the next interpellation that I asked to speak.As Mr. President urged me to speak, I did so now.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Then I may have to apologize if it has been mixed up by the EPP Group.In any case, you are on the agenda for this question and Mrs Zovko will speak for the EPP Group on the next question.So let's do it pragmatically like this: You won't be on the agenda for the next big question.I would then definitely give you the floor again.Mr Preda, can you help explain something?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – For UNRWA, yes.

name: President. –
text: Mr Preda, your name is later down the list for this Interpellation.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – Ok. thanks a lot.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Socialists and Democrats reject this infamous attack against the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA), the UN agency providing protection and assistance to the Palestinian refugees in the Middle East for almost seven decades. A huge number of Palestinian refugees have been facing an extremely precarious situation, as they are in the front line of a series of regional conflicts that converge and amplify one another. Palestinian refugees who periodically had few conflicts live and survive in extreme poverty and insecurity. The Syrian crisis has exacerbated the situation in the twelve Palestinian camps existing in this country, and in spite of achieving remarkable results in the field, UNRWA’s capabilities are stretched beyond limits. This problem is recurring every time, and I think that we as the Union and we as the European Parliament should fight, together with the Commission, every year to face our responsibility and, together with our other international partners, find a more stable solution for UNRWA funding. Finally, this interpellation does not represent in anyway the position of this Parliament. The Rules of Procedure have been abused and misused by a minority group on the right – I would say a far-right minority group. We continue to strongly support the Agency and praise UNRWA for their most-needed, difficult but also extraordinary efficient work they are doing. I will tell the colleagues from EFDD: they should go one single day to see how UNRWA is operating in those camps – what they are doing – and only after to come here and to spread these unacceptable lies. UNRWA is a part of the solution and not a part of the problem when it comes to ensuring stability in the Middle East today and achieving a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians tomorrow. I won’t comment on or question today the honesty of EFDD – this is not the case. Instead of any other conclusion, Mr President and Madam Commissioner, I can only say: for some people infamy has no limits, and we should stop this process in the future.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Boștinaru!I want to say again clearly: It was obviously not the mistake of Mr Ruas.I can't fix it like this now, we're going to run through the agenda.Normally, as the strongest group, the EPP Group would of course have the right to speak as the first group.It's a little different today.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, there is no doubt that the issue of damage from forest fires is very important, so I support my colleague's efforts, but this will most likely be discussed in the next paragraph. name: Jozo Radoš
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group of Representatives. - Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, the Palestinian-Israeli conflict has burdened international relations from the very beginning, especially political relations in the Middle East. The position of the Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza has greatly contributed to mistrust in the politics of the Western world, including the politics of the European Union, and the radicalization of the Islamic and Arab worlds. I therefore support the goal of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, and in particular its work in the field of education, which is the main purpose of its existence and activities. I also support the assistance provided by the European Union to the work of this Agency and, in general, to the financing and operation of the Palestinian State. Of course, if there are indications of abuse in the activities of the Agency and the use of financial resources and facilities of the Agency, these abuses should be carefully investigated. But it would be fair for the proponents to offer concrete evidence for the allegations of abuse they cited in their interpellation.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in a few days I will go with a delegation from my parliamentary group to Palestine to see the situation with my own eyes and to bring my solidarity and that of my group to the Palestinian people, as I have already done in August 2014. I would like to testify to the President of my bewilderment at the shameful behavior of the EFDD group which, first, on the basis of slander, raises this question and does not even appear in the Chamber. I think it must be clear that the slanders present in the interpellation are rejected by the whole Parliament and the whole European Union. If there are Palestinian refugees, it is because the Palestinians are still a stateless people, because Israel occupies a territory that is not hers, and because it forcibly expelled Palestinians from its land. This Parliament should discuss not the closure but how to increase support for UNRWA, how to put an end to the Israeli occupation of the Palestinian territories and the continuing violation by the Israeli government of all UN resolutions on the conflict, international conventions on human rights, up to the last abuse: the denial of residence permits for European citizens married to Palestinians. We should discuss this, how to ensure that, for example, the European Union suspends the association agreement with Israel. I think that what we have been asked to discuss here today is truly a shameful slander, which tarnishes this Parliament.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, on August 31, the Foreign Affairs Committee voted for the opinion that I drafted on the 2018 budget. In this text, we stressed in particular how important it is for the Union to continue to play a central role in supporting the Middle East peace process, the Palestinian Authority and UNRWA. An attempt has also been made, through budgetary amendments, to respond to the financial difficulties facing UNRWA, which has to meet the growing needs of some five million Palestinian refugees. Our support for UNRWA is constant and rightly seen as part of our strategy for engaging in peace in the region. In the context I have just recalled, I find the debate we are having today, barely two weeks after this vote, on the idea of ​​abolishing UNRWA incongruous. What signal are we sending if, on the one hand, we vote for budget amendments that are favorable to UNRWA and, on the other hand, we debate its abolition. That being said, my group has always supported the strengthening of the accountability of all the organizations that benefit from European funds. Of course, we can always improve things and verify that taxpayer money is used responsibly to achieve our strategic objectives in accordance with our values. It would be better to do this by acting constructively rather than talking about abolition.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, what I wanted to ask my colleagues from EFDD, but obviously they did not have the courage to come to ask them a question and to hear our discussion, one is actually a very simple question.I wanted to ask them if it’s better to fund war or finance peace, if it’s better to spend taxpayers ’money on creating extra madness in the Middle East, or it’s better to help common sense and reason in the Middle East, because that’s what it’s all about.We all know that in the end, always and most of all, the European Union and its citizens finance especially peace and especially development.Fortunately, the war is much less funded almost everywhere.As there are no ones who have asked this question, I want to express my simple position.I support the work of this United Nations agency and simply wish it much success.

text: Als nächster Punkt der Tagesordnung folgt die Aussprache über die Große Anfrage gemäß Artikel 130b der Geschäftsordnung von Nicola Caputo, Fernando Ruas, Ivan Jakovčić, Eric Andrieu, Clara Eugenia Aguilera García, Ana Gomes, Renata Briano, Simona Bonafè, Ricardo Pargnão , Pina Picierno, Ivica Tolić, Aldo Patriciello, Biljana Borzan, Claudia Țapardel, Dubravka Šuica, Brando Benifei, Doru-Claudian Frunzulică, Alberto Cirio, Liliana Rodrigues, Barbara Spinelli, Andrea Cozzolino, Michela Giuffrida, Tonino Picula, Viotti Zoffoli, Daniele , Isabella De Monte, Martin Häusling, Monica Macovei, Takis Hadjigeorgiou, Željana Zovko, Merja Kyllönen, Igor Šoltes, Luigi Morgano, Silvia Costa, Elena Gentile, Alessandra Mussolini, Momchil Nekov, Salvatore Domenico Pogliese, Peter Kouroumbashev, Stefano Maullu, Mari Petir , Franz Obermayr, Tibor Szanyi, Miltiadis Kyrkos, Stelios Kouloglou, Viorica Dăncilă, Eleonora Forenza, Curzio Maltese, Piernicola Pedicini, Manolis Ke falogiannis, Barbara Kappel, Enrique Guerrero Salom an die Kommission betreffend Waldbrände in der Europäischen Union in diesem Sommer (O-000063/2017 - 2017/2842 (RSP)) (B8-0327 / 2017).

name: Nicola Caputo
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the summer just past has seen an unprecedented peak of fires: the number of fires that devastated an area of ​​greater Europe when Luxembourg has almost tripled the average of the last eight years, passing from 404 to 1 068. The countries most affected were those of the Mediterranean area - Italy, Portugal, Spain, France, Croatia and Greece - which suffered numerous human losses and material damage on a large scale. Italy in particular, according to the European Commission's Emergency Response Coordination Center, last summer had 371 fires and was the first country in Europe for the number of forest fires, which erased 72,000 hectares of vegetation . It is often difficult for Member States to tackle fires of this magnitude alone: ​​as highlighted by the European Court of Auditors in a report of 24 February 2015, EU funding for the prevention of damage to forests caused by fires and natural disasters, as well as the reconstruction of forest potential, are not managed effectively enough. In fact, to date there is no specific legislation in the European Union concerning the fight against fires and droughts, and the lack of a broader political strategy regarding fire prevention is becoming increasingly evident. For these reasons we have presented this main question to ask the Commission whether it does not consider it appropriate to mobilize the European Union Solidarity Fund and apply it flexibly to deal with the serious damage caused by fires; if it does not consider it appropriate to initiate European intervention mechanisms by creating adequate legal and budgetary instruments to achieve better coordination of Member States' policies in this field and to optimize the European instruments available; and if, finally, it has intention to present specific measures for the prevention and fight against fires and droughts in the European Union, including, for example, agricultural aid for the creation and maintenance of fire protection strips, in order to achieve better coordination between the policies of the Statesmembers in this area and make the best use of the Community instruments available.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking you all for this major interpellation. Forest fires are currently a major concern for the European Union, and you know very well that the Commission is ready to make every effort to ensure EU solidarity reaches all those people and all those areas that were hit by the dramatic forest fires of this summer and avoid such catastrophes happening again. EU solidarity is active at all stages – prevention, intervention and construction – and it is channelled through a broad range of instruments. First of all, the European Solidarity Fund. This fund can be mobilised to help with recovery from major and regional natural disasters. However, support is subject to two conditions – first, total direct damage should exceed a threshold which is specific for each Member State or region, and second, national authorities have to submit an application within twelve weeks of the start of the disaster. Without an application the Commission may not take the initiative. Among the many countries affected by forest fires during the summer, only one, namely Portugal, has submitted so far an application for financial assistance, which is currently being assessed by the European Commission.  The second instrument that is available is the Cohesion Policy. The Cohesion Policy can support, among others, replacement of small and medium-sized enterprises’ productive capacity as well as public infrastructure and equipment. This is what we put in place, for example, for Portugal in August, sent through a swift reallocation of funding within Portuguese programmes with a total maximum budget of EUR 45 million from the Regional Development Fund. Other EU response tools are also available to assist in fire emergencies. The European Commission’s Emergency Response Coordination Centre monitors forest fires 24 hours per day using the European Forest Fire Information System, and close coordination is maintained between these two bodies with the countries at high risk of forest fires. Assistance may be provided by the EU civil protection mechanism – we mean fire fighting equipment and personnel. The Copernicus Emergency Management Service provides satellite maps for forest fire related emergencies to the European Forest Fire Information System. The European Union’s main arm to protect forests is the European Agriculture Rural Development Fund, yet not because of the means it devotes to fire fighting. Experience shows that large-scale, catastrophic mega fires, if not intentional, are driven mainly by two factors. First, extreme weather conditions such as extended heatwaves, drought and strong winds, which are intensifying due to climate change. Second, fire-proneness of forests due to natural resource mismanagement and unsustainable land-use decisions such as abandonment of sustainable forest management practices. These factors are largely regardless of how much we spend on firefighting means and preparedness. On the contrary, more investments are needed on forest fire prevention, on boosting the health and resilience of forest ecosystems. This is exactly what the European Agricultural Development Fund promotes, through three measures: investments in preventive actions to reduce the consequences of natural disasters on agricultural areas; prevention and restoration of damage to forests from fires; and risk management tools. So thank you very much, and I am waiting for your debate.

name: Željana Zovko
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. President, Honorable Commissioner Crețu, as one of the co-signatories of the interpellation on fires in the European Union this summer, I am obliged to participate in today's debate and warn of the extent of damage caused by fires and prolonged droughts in southern Europe, especially in Croatia and in its area of ​​Dalmatia. Thus, according to the first estimates, the data of 42 million kuna of damage without burned forests was found only in the Split-Dalmatia County, and only during the big fire in the vicinity of Split. I believe that the amount of damage will be much higher when all the data from the burned areas in Dalmatia, but also in the rest of Croatia, are finally added up. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank all the volunteer and public fire brigades, but also all Croatian citizens who have tirelessly and unceasingly helped in defending property, nature and, most importantly, protecting and saving human lives. However, in order not to rest only on our thanks and words of encouragement to our firefighters and citizens, I would like to take this opportunity to point out the shortcomings in the existing solidarity mechanisms and instruments of the European Union. Thus, for example, there is no flexibility within existing instruments to help Member States affected by large forest fires. What interests me, Commissioner, is when the Commission intends to mobilize the European Solidarity Fund to help Croatia and other Member States. Do you think that after these fires, a single legislative framework and instrument and body are needed to help coordinate policies and preventive measures in the fight against such disasters?

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: - Mr President, my apologies for what happened and also my thanks for the understanding you showed when giving me the floor. In July, I requested this debate on forest fires. At the time, as I said, only Portugal and Spain were affected, today we add Croatia, France, Greece and Italy, which demonstrates the scope of this sad reality. In fact, and in my country alone, 214 thousand hectares of forest burned this year and until August 31. This figure represents more than 234% of the burnt area than the average of the last ten years for the same period and in the context of European aid it is important to know whether the Commission envisages the flexible application of the Solidarity Fund, as is now requested here. It is that, on the ground, Commissioner, the people need immediate help and, if national governments are primarily responsible for such aid, it is also important that they know, in time, the European amounts allocated to them. I therefore warn, and once again, of the absolute need for quick, simplified and flexible assistance to the survivors' families, workers who have lost their jobs, affected companies, firefighters and municipalities. Here, too, the European Union can help, in fact according to the information that the Commissioner has given us, and which is already being done in my country.

name: Urszula Krupa
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! I would like to support the postulates and questions of the authors of the interpellation concerning forest fires that have hit the Union, and especially the southern countries, causing fatalities and huge damage. The protection of forests is essential, and their beneficial influence on the environment or climate cannot be overestimated and even difficult to specify. You have to be aware that new forests will not emerge in the EU until several dozen years. I am speaking on this subject also because Poland suffered huge losses, not as a result of fires, but after the storms that took place in the second decade of August, when almost eight million cubic trees were felled. Forty thousand hectares of forests in the south-west of my country are destroyed, where several people have also died and several thousand buildings have been destroyed. The damage is usually superficial, but especially during fires, entire stands are destroyed, enormous natural losses arise, habitats of valuable bird species, lairs of wild animals and habitats of valuable plant species are destroyed. That is why we need community protection, solidarity and support both in terms of protecting forests against fires and other natural disasters, not forgetting to educate the public in this field. It is necessary to mobilize the European Union Solidarity Fund and apply it in a flexible manner to remove damage caused by fires, droughts and natural disasters.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group of Representatives. - Mr. President, the Mediterranean was burning again this year, this summer. In Croatia, the worst was in Dalmatia. We cannot predict fires, they are difficult to control, but we have to do something. We have to put our hand on our heart and say, first of all, and ask ourselves if we have done enough, because the tragedies that have happened all over the Mediterranean are truly amazing. We need more solidarity in Europe and we need to use the Solidarity Fund in a more flexible way. We need to help people, because there have been really great tragedies. I would like to emphasize, Madam Commissioner, that I wrote to you, and, as you know, I spoke about the Adriatic-Ionian macro-strategy here in this House, and in that strategy I wrote that we need one Adriatic Disaster Prevention Center, one joint Adriatic and Ionian Center. sea. Let’s do something when we talk about fires, we can do it, we can fund it, it can help people. That’s at least minimally what we can do, but let’s do it right away. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I noticed my colleague Mr Jakovčić made very clear proposals, and I believe that solidarity is a great value, but this value should somehow be translated into action. I would like to ask Mr Jakovčić: apart from the crisis centre, do you think that there should be some regional capacities established in order to cope with disasters much better? I mean, countries in a region might cooperate – have joint firefighters or something. What is your opinion about this?

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- Mr. Auštrevičius, of course I know you as a person who always has very concrete ideas and suggestions and I fully support what you are saying.It is on the trail of what I have suggested that you in a way suggest the cooperation of countries that are close.I will only mention Canadian;Italy and Croatia share a huge Adriatic coast, and we are so close, and we really should have a common center, because the Canadian can cross the Adriatic in a few minutes.So, I absolutely agree with you.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Jakovčić!It is nice that you are now showing your mutual appreciation, which you normally only share in the group, in a public session.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Portugal recorded historical numbers of fires and burnt areas this summer, some of brutal proportions and consequences, which cannot be justified by the intense heat waves. Two months after the approval of the budgetary reinforcement of the Solidarity Fund, it is important to ascertain the amounts actually made available to the country, as well as to understand how they were mobilized and how support for victims and populations was effected, on the one hand, in ecological recovery. structural, on the other. But we take this opportunity to reinforce what we have long advocated: the need to modify the Fund's mobilization rules, ensuring a more flexible, timely mobilization and covering a wider range of disasters, but also affirming that defending the forest and preventing fires it requires another policy and financial and human resources. The community approach to disaster prevention and many of the proposals that this Parliament approved in 2010 - highlighting the proposal to create an appropriate financial framework for disaster prevention capable of financing actions in areas such as forestry planning or the maintenance of agricultural activity in areas affected by depopulation - are still far from being implemented. Much remains to be done and action and measures are urgently needed in this regard.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, fires happen in particular places. Countries do not catch fire, nor even do regions. It is houses that catch fire, trees catch fire, woods catch fire, villages, even whole communities can get caught in fires, but it is all essentially local. The best approach to help put fires out and help cope with the consequences of fires is to do it locally. Victims of fires need people on the spot, and they and we need resources applied in exactly the right way at the right time and in the right place, that is to say locally. Therefore, it follows that fires are the ultimate example in which to apply subsidiarity. Of course, neighbours must help out, and of course, all donations are welcome and all decent people will indeed help. But this is yet another and regrettable example of the EU Commission thinking that big is best. This is incorrect. It is local that is best – and more than that, micro is magic. We can help people best – individuals, communities and people caught in the middle – locally. What we do not need is the slow-moving, Kafkaesque EU bureaucracy which has proven itself over and over again to be dysfunctional and unhelpful. To depart for my prepared text: there was a fire earlier today in the Hemicycle – a fire of democracy. It is not often that I agree with a Member of GUE/NGL, but the gentleman was right. It was profoundly undemocratic for a member of the Commission – the executive – to intervene directly in a parliamentary debate. This was fire of democracy, and colleagues should consider that a Parliament should not accept intervention in this way, from a member of the executive. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: blue card issue.- Mr Dartmouth!I want to ask you a question.As you are so passionate about criticizing both the European Commission and my colleague Corina Crețu, whom I would like to praise because she is a Romanian Commissioner, she is a Social Democrat, she is working hard to solve the problems you are talking about as effectively as possible.But my question to you is, in principle, why are you here in this Chamber criticizing the European Commission if your political group is fundamentally opposed to the European Union?Well, maybe it's enough to talk in this style and just vacate the Chamber?

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – As Donald Tusk, the President of the Council, pointed out in a prepared statement the day after the Brexit referendum, all UK citizens and all the citizens of other countries represented by members of the EFDD Group are fully bound by all the laws, rules, regulations and directives of the European Union. We therefore have a moral obligation to represent our constituents and to defend our constituents from all too many examples of bad decisions and bad decision-making by a number of Commissioners, many of whom are frankly just not up to the job.

name: Der Präsident.
text: - I would like to add one more sentence to what was not said this afternoon shortly before the vote.According to the relevant provisions, the Commission has the right to intervene at any time.That is why the indignant reaction to Mrs Mogherini - which did not come from you, Mr Dartmouth, but you have now brought it up again - was in no way appropriate.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, more and more often we see a drop in rainfall in spring, and therefore more drought in the thickets and in the woods. When added to a heat wave, fairly high temperatures - like those we experienced this summer - and strong winds, we obviously have fires breaking out, especially around the Mediterranean. In addition, the simultaneity of fires is an additional difficulty in the fight against fires. However, I have often heard that we talk about solidarity funds and we are right. But under today's conditions, even firebreaks in well-maintained forests cannot prevent fires from sparking, when there are very strong winds, tens of meters, or even hundreds of meters. Besides the Solidarity Fund, which intervenes when it is too late, when it is necessary to compensate the victims, could we not think of a mixed private / public fund which could, for example, integrate town halls, insurance companies and also a series of actors to have a prevention fund that can better equip the most sensitive areas, for example in reserve canadairs - even if I know it is very expensive - which could strengthen the already existing teams in the field to better fight fires, especially when there is a simultaneous declaration of fires.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I congratulate Mr Caputo and those who have signed on this issue. He is very much in place. Not only the whole of Southern Europe is burning this year, one of the big Bulgarian mountains - Pirin is also burning. There the damage is in the millions and will be repaired, as you know a forest is restored by the order of decades. Many colleagues have spoken about the Solidarity Fund, but it will have to pay back damages that have already occurred. It is much cheaper and much more sensible to talk about what needs to be done and what can be done to prevent fires on such a scale. And here, colleague Caputo, we cannot talk only about fire-fighting clearings, they can be made somewhere, but in bio-reserves, in national parks, nature parks such clearings cannot be made because of the legislation and the difficult-to-access terrain. And here, Commissioner, I have concrete proposals for you. First of all, it can and should be considered to jointly purchase equipment from the Member States, helicopters, planes, seaplanes, which together extinguish large areas between countries. Secondly, volunteers from different countries need to be trained and equipped to fight fires.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, the fires that have engulfed Croatia this year have not been remembered in the last few decades.In August alone, 44,000 hectares were burned with great material damage, but fortunately without human casualties.Summer fires are a permanent problem in Europe, especially in its Mediterranean part.I therefore thank my colleague Caputo and the other colleagues who raised this issue, and I equally support their proposals to activate the European Solidarity Fund and establish a European intervention mechanism.I think that these instruments, which should definitely be activated, should focus on solidarity in firefighting and perhaps, more importantly, on joint fire prevention in the border areas of the European Union.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ... that I am still fond of the division of powers which are the foundation of the rule of law and, therefore, that a European Commissioner can intervene in the course of a vote is something that, fortunately, still surprises me and I think it is something that is not in keeping with the exaltation of the powers of the European Parliament and their strengthening, which we very often hear from that seat. So, let me strongly disagree with what you have said. I thank Mr Caputo for promoting this question, which I helped to support through my signature. I fully share what my colleague Pimenta Lopes said about the Solidarity Fund, that is, on the fact that the austerity and cuts policies have made fire prevention and interventions more difficult. I also take the liberty of saying that the Member States have not always done what they could do, that the Italian government should perhaps buy more Canadair and less F35 and that the abolition of the State Forestry Corps certainly did not help to adequately address this situation.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for their words. I think the tensions that appeared here are not about this debate and about myself, but I thank you for your words. I presented in my first speech exactly how many tools we have to deal with fires, and I can assure you that for us it was a priority during the summer. It was by chance that I was on permanence when Portugal suffered the fires. Each day I was in contact with the Ministers, in Greece and Italy also. You know that you, the Members of the European Parliament, voted yesterday for 95% from European funds to be used for natural disasters. Yesterday you also approved the Commission proposal to help Italy with EUR 1.2 billion after the earthquake. In terms of the fires, I think the richness of the debate today shows just how complex the issue of forest fires is and requires joining forces, knowledge and expertise beyond silos and beyond borders. To respond to your questions, I would like to say that you are right when you say that everything is local, but the European Union activates assistance only when locals ask for help, so it took less than 12 hours this summer for Portugal to receive help from France, and also France, Italy and Spain. To give you an example: as I said at the beginning, we have a Solidarity Fund, we have Cohesion Funds. Portugal has asked for change in the operational programme, and in a few days we will change and help Portugal with EUR 45 million to deal with Portugal. We also have other instruments, for instance the Civil Protection Mechanism. The mechanism was activated by Portugal in the early hours of Sunday, 18 June, and through the mechanism an immediate offer was made, I can say, within one hour, of three planes from France. The French fleet arrived in the affected area on the same day and began operations immediately. The other eight planes from Italy and Spain were offered on 18 June and arrived on 18 and 19 June. So I just wanted to give you some examples of what we are doing with this. What you said on prevention is very important. We have investments on prevention, on boosting the health and resilience of forests’ ecosystems. This is exactly what the European Agricultural Rural Development Fund promotes through the measures I presented at the beginning. So, thank you once again for this debate. I will go back to Brussels with this message from you, with an unwavering will to work closely with you and the Member States in finding a European response to these very dramatic challenges for the countries and for the people.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.(The sitting was closed at 3:55 p. M.)
